item.title: Rates | Beijing announces that it is “evaluating” the US Supreme Court’s decision
item.description: The Chinese Ministry of Commerce announced yesterday that it is “evaluating” the content and impact of the United States Supreme Court's decision on the tariffs imposed by the Donald Trump Administration, reiterating its opposition to “unilateral” measures. In a statement, the ministry indicated that it “took note” of the court decision in the dispute over tariffs and that it is carrying out a “full assessment” of its implications. China “systematically opposes unilateral tariff measures” and reiterates that “the trade war has no winners and protectionism has no way out”, said the ministry, after the United States Supreme Court ruled that the Trump Administration exceeded its powers by invoking the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) as a legal basis to impose tariff rates. The ministry added that the so-called “reciprocal tariffs” and tariffs related to fentanyl constitute ‘unilateral’ measures that, according to Beijing, “not only violate international economic and trade rules”, but also the “domestic law” of the United States, and “do not serve the interests of either party”. Beijing also insists that relations between the two powers must be managed based on cooperation. “The facts have repeatedly demonstrated that China and the United States benefit when they cooperate and are harmed when they confront each other,” said the ministry, which urged Washington to “cancel” the unilateral tariffs imposed on its trading partners. Beijing said it has observed that the United States is “preparing” to resort to alternative measures such as “trade investigations” with the aim of maintaining the imposition of tariffs on its partners, and warned that China will “maintain close surveillance” and “firmly protect” its interests.

item.title: National security | Defended legal basis for the absence of defense
item.description: Wang Yu, professor at the Faculty of Law of the University of Macau, argued in an opinion article in the newspaper Ou Mun that the fact that decisions and opinions of the MSAR State Security Defense Commission cannot be appealed are well supported legally. The proposed law for its reformulation is currently under special analysis in the Legislative Assembly. The academic also argues that the lack of appeal has a constitutional basis, referring to the cases of France and the USA, where there is a regime in which the courts do not have jurisdiction over disputes arising from political issues. He also argues that, in the world, there is a general consensus on the fact that highly political acts cannot be prosecuted in ordinary courts. Wang Yu also spoke of the basic law of the judicial organization of Macau, which determines that “issues of a political nature” are excluded from administrative, tax and customs litigation, as well as “acts carried out in the exercise of political functions and liability for damages resulting from that exercise”. This means, for the professor, that the courts cannot deal with acts arising from the exercise of political functions.

item.title: Scam | Elderly loses 1.6 million in illegal scheme
item.description: An elderly man was scammed out of around 1.6 million Hong Kong dollars after believing he was investing in an alleged Macau casino scam, which promised gamblers guaranteed winnings. The case was reported yesterday by the Judiciary Police (PJ) with the man being lured into the scam by a contact he met online. According to the fraudster, if the elderly man played with him, through a mobile application, he would always win. The games were allegedly taking place in one of the local casinos. After winning HK$2,400 following a HK$1,000 bet, the man believed the scam was real and transferred HK$870,000 to an account indicated by the online contact. However, when the application started showing earnings of 2 million Hong Kong dollars, the man was unable to access the money. He was told that access was dependent on further transfers to the account, which the man did until he accumulated losses of 1.6 million Hong Kong dollars. At that time, and without being able to raise the money, he filed a complaint with the PJ. Crime | Asks for money to display online and ends up in discussion A 26-year-old man from the Interior was arrested after trying to steal 170,000 Hong Kong dollars, with the excuse that he wanted to make a video to show himself on social media. The case was revealed yesterday by the Judiciary Police (PJ) and took place last Saturday, in a casino in Cotai. According to the outlines presented, the detainee approached the member of a money exchange group, and asked him for permission to film with 170 thousand Hong Kong dollars in chips and show himself on social media. In return, the suspect promised to exchange money later in the respective amount. However, when he received the chips, the man tried to escape, which led to an argument with the victim. The case caught the attention of casino security, which alerted the authorities, who arrested the suspect. The group member is also being investigated for the crime of illegal money exchange. CPSP | Woman detained upon entering Macau A woman from the Interior was arrested by the Public Security Police Corps, after taking possession of a cell phone she found inside a bus, in December. The case was publicized yesterday, and the woman was detained on Thursday, when she tried to enter Macau through Portas do Cerco. Questioned by authorities, the woman acknowledged the crime, which she justified with “momentary greed”. The detainee also confessed that the cell phone was being used inside and that upon returning to Macau she did not bring the rest of the equipment. In turn, the owner of the cell phone, a tourist, also from the interior, valued the object at around 4,500 patacas, when she complained about the loss. The case was referred to the Public Prosecutor's Office and the woman is indicted for the crime of illegitimate appropriation in the case of accession or found property, which carries a prison sentence of up to one year.

item.title: Real Estate | Purchases tripled at the beginning of January
item.description: The year started with the highest number of transactions since 2018, with 384 housing purchases and sales. However, prices continue to fall, even if the reduction is increasingly slight In the first half of January, demand for housing more than tripled, with 384 deals registered, the highest for the first half of January since 2018, when 426 housing purchases and sales were recorded. The most recent figures were updated on the Financial Services Directorate (DSF) portal, and show that prices were stable, albeit with a slight reduction. According to official data, the market showed signs of vitality mainly in the Macau Peninsula, with the total number of transactions reaching 299, higher than the 96 recorded in the same period last year, a difference of 203 purchases and sales. The growth trend did not stop at the Peninsula. In the Taipa market, the number of transactions also more than doubled, with 58 transactions recorded at the beginning of this year, compared to 20 transactions last month. In Coloane, 27 housing purchases and sales were recorded, an increase compared to the nine recorded at the beginning of 2025. January's growth is equally significant when the comparison is made with the beginning of December last year. At the beginning of January, there were 297 more transactions than those registered at the beginning of the previous month, when there were 87. The market showed greater demand compared to data from the beginning of December in Macau, and in the Peninsula 96 transactions were registered, in Taipa 17 and in Coloane three transactions. The other side In relation to housing purchase prices, the beginning of January brought a slight reduction, to an average of 69,241 patacas per square meter. Compared to the same period last year, the data reveals a decrease in housing values ​​of around 0.92 percent. According to the most recent data, the highest prices were charged in Coloane, where the square meter reached 74,190 patacas. Prices on the Macau Peninsula were above what happens in Taipa, with a price of 69,499 patacas per square meter, while on the Peninsula the price was 66,867 patacas per square meter. However, the comparison with December shows a higher price reduction. At the beginning of the last month of last year, the average price per square meter was 78,838 patacas, while the most recent price was 69,241 patacas, which meant a reduction of 12.17 percent.

item.title: Illegal pensions | Demanded fight against online advertisements
item.description: Song Pek Kei calls for a fight against those who publish advertisements on social media offering illegal accommodation in private homes, and for the accounts to be banned. Both the deputy and tourism entrepreneur Andy Wu highlight the poor supply of legal accommodation at affordable prices as one of the reasons for irregularities A few weeks before the Lunar New Year holidays, at the end of January, advertisements for renting rooms for tourists who were considering visiting Macau during the holidays began to appear on social media, especially Chinese ones. Although the phenomenon is not new to the region, some publications offered “beds” in Macau for between 100 and 150 renminbis. Song Pek Kei once again spoke out against illegal pensions. In an article published yesterday in the Citizen newspaper, the deputy linked to the Fujian community suggests that the Government establish a coordination mechanism with social networks, such as Douyin (Chinese TikTok), to eliminate publications offering rooms in illegal guesthouses and ban the accounts that share them. The deputy considers that, with the end of the pandemic and the paralysis of tourism, the phenomenon of illegal boarding houses has returned in force, with more cases compared to the past, following the increase in the number of tourists visiting Macau and the successive records of arrivals. It is recalled that in the first 20 days of the year, authorities inspected 25 apartments suspected of illegally providing accommodation, of which 17 were sealed. Song Pek Kei highlighted that illegal guesthouses persist based on two situations: unaffordable prices and low supply of budget hotels, and people staying in Macau too long. The deputy indicated that at the moment, around 6,000 people are in the territory overstaying. From the competition With hotel rooms at unmatched prices in Zhuhai, both Song Pek Kei and travel agency entrepreneur and association leader Andy Wu believe that the local low-cost hotel offer is not enough, despite legal changes that now allow the offer of capsule hotels. An opinion shared by the president of the Macau Tourism Industry Association, Andy Wu, who also told the Cidadão newspaper highlighted the limited supply of low-cost options. For the director, offering accommodation to tourists who are illegally in Macau harms the healthy development of the tourism industry. Furthermore, he pointed out that the prices between budget hotels and five-star hotels are not that different, especially on weekdays, and that they are far from the prices charged in Zhuhai, with rooms between 100 and 200 renminbi.

item.title: Natural Gas | Renminbi worth new price cuts
item.description: The devaluation of the currency led the Government to announce yesterday the third annual cut in the price of natural gas, with the reduction varying between 0.56 percent and 0.96 percent. With the new cuts, all prices are below the values ​​of 2022, the year before the invasion of Ukraine and a general rise in the cost of gas Since yesterday, the price of natural gas has been reduced by between 0.56 percent and 0.96 percent. The announcement was made yesterday morning, through a statement from the Directorate of Environmental Protection Services (DSPA). “In response to the decline in the international price of natural gas in recent years and fluctuations in the exchange rate of the renminbi in relation to the pataca, the cost of purchasing natural gas to supply Macau has fallen”, it was justified. “The sales prices of natural gas charged to the four groups of customers decreased by around 0.6 percent to 1 percent”, it was added. With the changes, residential customers, the so-called Group A, will have the smallest reduction, of 0.56 percent, with the price dropping to 6.7403 patacas per cubic meter of gas, compared to 6.7782 patacas per cubic meter of gas. In relation to Group B of natural gas consumers, non-commercial residents, the cut is 0.59 percent, to 6.3786 patacas per cubic meter, when previously the price was 6.4165 patacas per cubic meter. In Group C, large customers, a cut of 0.60 percent is applied, to 6.3198 patacas per cubic meter, from 6.3568 patacas per cubic meter. The biggest reduction targets Group D of customers, also known as “special”, who will benefit from a price cut of 0.96 percent, to 3.9447 patacas per cubic meter. Until yesterday, the price was .9825 patacas per cubic meter. Before the war With the new prices coming into force, the cost of natural gas is below 2022 levels, even before the Ho Iat Seng Government announced increases of 8.2 percent to 14.3 percent, an indirect consequence of Russia's invasion of Ukraine and a spike in demand in international markets. Before this increase, residential customers paid MOP6.9998 per cubic meter, while Group B customers paid MOP6.4122 per cubic meter, Group C customers paid MOP6.3364 per square meter and Group D customers paid MOP4.0126 per cubic meter. The annual price reductions since the 2023 increase contributed to the new reality, with the cuts varying between 3.14 percent and 8.13 percent, with the changes being justified by the devaluation of the renminbi, the Macao SAR supply market, and also international prices.

item.title: Game | Dealers will operate exchange offices

item.title: AL | Project presented that reduces Government interventions
item.description: The Rules and Mandates Committee presented a bill to reduce Government interventions during oral interpellation sessions. The option reduces the Executive's intervention by five minutes and adds more questions in a block The Legislative Assembly (AL) Rules and Mandates Committee presented a bill that will reduce the time for Executive interventions. The project with the changes was published on the hemicycle portal. According to the current model, when a deputy makes an oral question, members of the Executive have an initial response period of 10 minutes. After the first explanations, the deputy responsible for the interpellation may make a new intervention, to ask for additional clarifications. The Government's second response follows, which can last for five minutes. Once the interaction between the deputy responsible for the oral interpellation and the Government is over, the other deputies are authorized to intervene. The legislators' interventions are collected as a block, with the Executive having the right to a last 10-minute intervention, in which it can answer the questions. However, with the new proposal, the Government will have five minutes less to answer questions and the intervention in response to the request for clarification from the deputy who asked the initial questions will be concentrated with questions from other deputies. With the new model, members of the Executive only have to intervene twice, the first time to respond to the deputy and a second time to provide additional clarifications to that deputy and to answer questions from other legislators. Currently, they intervene three times. Joint interpellations The new project also changes the way oral interpellations signed by more than one deputy are conducted, a mechanism little used by the Legislative Assembly. According to the new project, when an oral interpellation is signed by more than one deputy, everyone will have the opportunity to ask for extra clarification, after the first intervention by members of the Executive. This is a different reality from the current one, in which only the first subscriber has the opportunity to intervene to ask for additional clarification. The second and subsequent signers cannot intervene either in the clarification phase or in the phase open to all other deputies. “The change that the Commission suggests to the Deputies ensures that all Deputies have the possibility of intervening in all interpellations, simultaneously allowing the Government to respond in a concentrated manner and at a single moment to all the questions raised”, was justified by the commission led by José Chui Sai Peng. Members of the Rules and Mandates Committee also include deputies Iau Teng Pio, Ângela Leong, Wong Kit Cheng, Song Pek Kei, Ip Sio Kai and Lei Wun Kong. Deputy card with changes The Rules and Mandates Committee proposed changes to the deputies' cards. According to the new model, the card now includes that Macau is a region of the People's Republic of China. Previously, the words People's Republic of China were only written in Chinese and within the Macao SAR symbol.

item.title: Rota das Letras | Film by Filipa Queiroz tells the story of homeless people from Alta de Coimbra
item.description: “Salatinas – Stories from the Old Alta of Coimbra” brings journalist Filipa Queiroz back to Macau, together with Rafael Vieira and Tiago Cerveira, co-authors of the documentary that is part of the Rota das Letras poster. The film tells the story of how, during the Estado Novo, around three thousand residents were expelled from Alta de Coimbra to allow the construction of the University City The University City in Alta de Coimbra is one of the city's tourist attractions, offering a stunning landscape. However, despite the beauty, the history of the construction of Cidade Universitária is full of suffering. In the documentary “Salatinas – Histórias da Velha Alta de Coimbra”, Filipa Queiroz, Rafael Vieira and Tiago Cerveira tell the story of the people who lived there in the 1940s and who found themselves suddenly homeless and without a plan B. The film is part of the poster for the Rota das Letras Literary Festival, which starts on March 5th. “We hope that, in Macau, the story can have an impact on everyone and in particular on the many people from Coimbra who we know reside in the territory”, Filipa Queiroz, who lived in Macau for several years, told HM and TDM – Macau Television. He is happy to return and to reveal this story unknown to many. And he gives the greatest praise to a festival that saw its birth 15 years ago. "I find the programming of this edition of Rota das Letras particularly courageous and relevant taking into account the contexts of Portugal, Macau and the world at the moment. We try to present the film where it makes sense and this is precisely the case. It is a film about people, but also about power, resistance, identity and the price of progress – themes that Macau knows so well", he highlighted. Filipa Queiroz came into contact with the story of these people through a report. “Rafael Vieira collaborated with me as a journalist, as he ran a publication in Coimbra [Coimbra Coolectiva] and told me that there was an [interesting] story there, and that he wanted to tell stories outside the box, more invisible, so to speak.” “Salatinas” was born, in reference to the name given to the people who lived in Alta de Coimbra, where there were already faculties of Literature, Law and the library. However, the Estado Novo evicted these people to build the currently existing buildings. Three thousand people left their homes, making this “one of the biggest urban transformations in Portugal, at a time when forced evictions, lack of access to housing and social segregation still make headlines”, describes the documentary’s synopsis. “Salatinas” is, therefore, “a trip down memory lane of the historic neighborhood wiped off the map under the regime’s impetus for renewal and the hubbub of students, tricanas, grocers and tailors that hides beneath the colleges”, adds the same synopsis. Leave quickly “What happened was the will of the Government at that time”, says Filipa Queiroz, to explain how a political decision changed the lives of so many people. "The University of Coimbra moved between Lisbon and Coimbra for many years, but then it was located in Coimbra and was the only one in the country, where the country's brains, the elite, were. There was then a decision that the university needed to grow and it had to be there. Salazar himself had studied there [Faculty of Law], in addition to there being a hospital. It wasn't about requalification, but they really destroyed what there was to build on top." What followed was a profound transformation in families in the area. Many never fully recovered. "When the destruction began, basically the Government warned the people who lived there that they all had to get out of there. They gave values ​​to the houses [for compensation], completely disproportionate and much lower than the value of the houses." "There is a person we mention in the film who was part of Salazar's circle, she was a doctor and an illustrious person, and she managed to have her house be one of the last to be removed, but she was still [homeless]. The poorer and more humble the people were, the quicker they had to leave, with one hand in front, the other behind. These people were thrown into neighborhoods of the city, which we can't even call neighborhoods, because it was something improvised at the time", says the co-author of the documentary. We are talking about areas with “fragile” houses. However, the precariousness of housing already came from behind. "Little houses were built that weren't of incredible quality, but the houses in Alta de Coimbra weren't there either, many of them. There was no basic sanitation, that needed to be requalified." A “self-identity” Filipa Queiroz highlights how “the solution was to end everything, not valuing the fact that it is a neighborhood, and with its own identity, and this is the main issue”. The neighborhood was Salatina. "Salatinas are people who worked or lived in the upper part of the city, or who were born there, and who crossed paths daily with the student elite. This diversity was very rich, which ended up having effects on the cultural aspect, on music, for example." Coimbra is a land associated with names in Portuguese music, especially interventionists, such as Zeca Afonso and Carlos Paredes, and among the “doctors” there were also “the futricas”, that is, “the people of Coimbra, but no one ever remembered those people”. Filipa Queiroz highlights that “many people, including those from Coimbra, don’t know what happened there”. “There was a city there, a very concentrated urban network full of people and life, with São João bonfires, cultural events, all very identity-related things.” All things destroyed with the requalification and expansion of the University City. Filipa Queiroz highlights that nowadays, and despite university experiences, the city's Alta no longer has the dynamics it once had. “It has that austere architecture and at night, nothing happens.” “Salatinas” gave voice to a topic that is rarely talked about. "People are very moved and feel very valued. We had people who went to the premiere [in Coimbra, in the Alta area] and who told us: 'It seems that there has been a repair here'. This even led to the death of some people, because they committed suicide out of grief, because they had to leave the place where they built their business and their lives". Filipa Queiroz also thanks Ricardo Pinto, director of Rota das Letras, for the invitation made. "He invited us knowing only the idea of ​​the film. This will allow my colleagues to discover, for the first time, this place, Macau, which is so special to me." Filipa Queiroz wants to continue telling stories through images. Having made documentaries linked to Macau, such as “Boat People” and “Once Upon a Time in Ka-Hó”, the idea is to continue in an audiovisual genre so close to journalism. "Documentaryism adds an artistic layer and time that journalism does not allow. Yes, I would like to make [more documentaries], that is always on my horizon. There are always challenges, with financing the work and the time that can be dedicated to it, but without a doubt, yes, I would like to continue."

item.title: Hong Kong | “The Nature of Why”, by Paraorchestra debuts in Asia
item.description: The No Limits Festival, in Hong Kong, hosts this weekend, from Friday to Sunday, the show “The Nature of Why”, by Paraorchestra, in what is the Asian debut of this renowned show. It is a combination of theater, orchestral music and dance, in a show that is guided by inclusion The neighboring region of Hong Kong is preparing to host, this weekend, from February 27th to March 1st, the show “The Nature of Why”, by Paraorchestra, part of the No Limits Festival. The public can enjoy sessions that “in a fun way” combine different artistic expressions such as “theater, live orchestra music and contemporary dance”, in a “totally inclusive and immersive” show, describes an official note from the organization. In what promises to be a “unique and intimate piece”, there are important names to take into account: the well-known British conductor and artistic director of the Paraorchestra, Charles Hazlewood, and the “acclaimed” Australian choreographer Caroline Bowditch. On stage, the musicians and dancers of Paraorchestra, which has already received several awards for its performances, “intertwine with the audience to the sound of a live cinematic soundtrack”, composed by Will Gregory, from Goldfrapp. “The Nature of Why” is inspired by “the boundless curiosity of Nobel Prize-winning theoretical physicist Richard Feynman and his search for the meaning of the world”, being described as an “inspiring and thought-provoking work that experiments with the nature of performance”. “As unexpected interactions and moments of joy emerge on the softly lit stage, the artists, musicians and audience become one in a sonic adventure in which every moment is a surprise”, states the same note. It is clear, therefore, that the public is invited to participate in the show, in a “unique format”. Those watching “are invited to come up to the stage to be closer to the action, free to walk, use a wheelchair or sit wherever they want”. It will be possible to “observe from a distance or get as close as you want to the virtuoso musicians and incredibly agile dancers, creating your own experience of this magical performance”. From integration The Paraorchestra is the first professional orchestra in the world composed of musicians with and without disabilities, having made its debut at the closing ceremony of the London 2012 Paralympic Games. Last year, the group won the “Ensemble Award” from the Royal Philharmonic Society. The group is based in Bristol, UK, describing themselves as a “fearless collective of musicians with and without disabilities”, who together present “innovative musical experiences, pushing the boundaries of musical creation to create art with passion and purpose”. The artistic direction is in charge of Charles Hazlewood. The show takes place in the Kwai Tsing Theater auditorium. From everyone and with everyone This year's lineup for the No Limits Festival – which runs until May – is full of presentations that aim to demonstrate that everyone can participate and create art. The theme of this year, the eighth edition, is “All of us, in every way”, being “a call to rethink the value of diversity through inclusion”. The organization's objective, as stated on the festival's website, is to seek to establish “a commitment to transforming difference and diversity into possibilities and connections”, with the idea that “inclusive arts can create a space for understanding”, that is, “a space where the imaginative potential of diversity can be seen and shared”. Another show included in the No Limits Festival is the theatrical performance “Two Blind Women in the Snowy Tokugawa Nights – Sleeping Fires by Kuro Tanino”, presented at the end of March at the Studio Theater of the Hong Kong Cultural Center, This commissioned work “tells the story of the blind masseuse Iku and the young apprentice Saya”, revealing itself “through a poetic combination of soundscapes, dialogues, gestures and aromas”. "This new commissioned play portrays the difficulties and pleasures of women's daily lives, as well as the complex issues of trust, secrecy and suspicion experienced by the inhabitants of the remote, snow-covered mountain village where they live. Contrasting the bonds of tradition and the women's search for independence and belonging, the play portrays their friendship and struggles, as well as the harshness and beauty of the natural world that surrounds them", describes the official note about this event. This is the latest work by theater director Kuro Tanino, being staged by Tanino's Niwa Gekidan Penino theater company.

item.title: Cooperation | South Korea and Brazil elevate bilateral relationship to “strategic partnership”
item.description: South Korea and Brazil agreed yesterday to elevate bilateral relations to the level of “strategic partnership”, at a summit held in Seoul between South Korean presidents, Lee Jae-myung, and Brazilian, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. “We have decided to elevate our bilateral relationship to a ‘strategic partnership'”, announced Lee, at a press conference after the meeting. The South Korean President explained that the “South Korea-Brazil Five-Year Action Plan”, adopted yesterday, will serve as an integral roadmap in areas such as politics, economics, practical cooperation and exchanges between citizens. Among the main results of the talks, he highlighted the push to resume negotiations for a trade agreement between South Korea and Mercosur, as well as the signing of eleven memorandums of understanding in sectors such as SMEs, health, agriculture, space, defense and aviation. In economic matters, the two countries agreed on the need to expand mutually beneficial cooperation and supported the prompt resumption of negotiations for a trade agreement between South Korea and Mercosur. Lula da Silva recalled that Brazil is home to the largest community of Korean origin in Latin America, with around fifty thousand people, and that K-pop, soap operas and South Korean cuisine have millions of consumers in Brazil.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Confucius (c.551-c.479 BC), according to what is written in the Analects (Lunyu), exclaimed one day: «How bad I have been! It's been a long time since I dreamed of the Duke of Zhou", which would only initially be understood as a lament about the loss of ideals but later taken literally, given the way his name captured the imagination of subsequent generations. Ji Dan, the Duke of Zhou, or Zhou Gong Dan, the philosopher who was regent at the beginning of the Zhou dynasty (r.1042-1035 BC), would already be an idealized figure of a master of thought who would have contributed to the elaboration of basic concepts such as the Heavenly Mandate to justify imperial power or participated in the most important texts that express the unique national perspective on the World and correct human conduct in it, such as the I Ching, the Classic of poetry (Shijing) or the book of Rites of Zhou (Zhouli). His name also appears as an initial symbolic author, to give him authority, linked to a Zhougong Jiemeng dream interpretation manual, which would initially be an aid for decision-making by leaders, but whose current version dates back to the Tang dynasty (618-907), adding divination, philosophy and popular culture. There you can find methods of oneiromancy such as fanmeng which performs the reverse interpretation of a dream; if it has distressing content it will obtain favorable results, or chaizi, the play on words that derives hidden meanings from them. If they were often dismissed as superstition, in certain periods dreams took on special importance. During the Ming dynasty, a high-ranking court official named Xu Xianqing (1537-1602) wanted to leave his autobiography to posterity in a precise and concrete way, requesting the help of two painters known for their refined realistic method of portraying buildings, clothing and situations, which included two dreams. Yu Shi and Wu Yue made this album from 1588 (twenty six double sheets, ink and color on silk, 62 x 58.5 cm, in the Palace Museum in Beijing) an enlightening document about the life and places in which a high-ranking official moved at that time. Each situation shown is accompanied by poems, comments or reflections written by the biographer himself, who says exactly how old he was when it occurred. In the first, he was twelve years old, his mother died and the boy is seen awake next to his sleeping father, dreaming of his mother standing by the door. In the fifteenth situation, the title says: «Dreaming about Confucius and convalescing», the 45-year-old employee is lying on the bed from which he emerges, like a balloon, another situation where Confucius is represented in a car. Volitional dreams that speak of filial love and loyalty to the Ming, the objective finally expressed in the title Huanji, «Traits of a public servant».

item.title: Ana Cristina Alves
item.description: Ana Cristina Alves – Assistant Researcher and Coordinator of the Educational Service of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center When listening to the Lecture on the Year of the Horse by Professor Wang Suoying at the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center regarding Chinese astrology and, specifically, the Fire Horse, which will inaugurate a new zodiacal period from February 17, 2026, I was able to recall some of the essential characteristics of the horse, transmitted by Chinese folk wisdom. Thus the horse begins to mythologically combine with the dragon in Dragon-Horse (龙马Lóngmǎ). This is an ideal combination, both on a mental and aesthetic level. From a spiritual point of view, the pair allows access to the organization of the world guided by intuitive wisdom, since it was on the back of this animal that the first legendary Chinese emperor Fuxi (伏羲) discovered the eight trigrams, fundamental for understanding the world. Let us remember them: the Creative Heaven (乾 Qián), the Receptive Earth (坤 Kūn), the abyssal Water (坎Kǎn), the clinging Fire (离 Lí), the awakening Thunder or Lightning (震 Zhèn), the gentle and penetrating Wind (巽 Xùn), the Joyful Lake (兑Duì) and the tranquil Mountain (艮 Gě) . These eight trigrams, with the qualities already mentioned, gave rise to the 64 hexagrams that make up the Classic of Changes, as I have already had the opportunity to mention, for example, in the text A Mulher na China (2007) or in the poetic work Visitações (2022). Through the composition of the trigrams into hexagrams, a world is exposed that poetically unfolds, depending on the intuitive and imaginative capabilities of each person, with precepts open to past, but also present and future existential experiences. Each person will be able to find what they are looking for at the same time as they create and recreate themselves with the help of the real elements of Heaven, Earth, Fire, Water and all others that they consider useful for their existential path, also traced with the help of the mind and, above all, the imagination. Still in its connection with the dragon in the proverbial expression “the Spirit of the Dragon-Horse” (龙马精神Lóngmǎ jīngshén) it represents the realization of an aesthetic ideal full of energy, beauty and power of transformation, just as these animals are for the Chinese. It starts, however, from a concrete floor and then flies. The land of popular wisdom tells us that the horse is a noble and loyal animal, which knows the path (老马识途Lǎomǎ-shítú), since experience is the mother of wisdom in it, but it is not just any experience: it is energetic, a good friend and loyal. This loyalty and energy could not be more noble, especially since since Chinese antiquity, equids have been the faithful companions of nobles. Therefore, the horse (马mǎ) also appears associated in language with nobility (侯hòu) and, through a game of homophonies, with the monkey (猴hóu), hence if in a painting the monkey appears on top of the horse, it means the possibility of receiving an honorific title, that is, of elevating the status. A horse can develop a lot of energy, with the most capable being those who travel a thousand miles (千里马Qiānlǐmǎ), whether equine or human, because there are also people overflowing with capacity and energy, like these animals, with those who had the blessing of being born under the good auspices of the Horse being in a more favorable position to cultivate enthusiasm and dynamism. This year of Fire. The suggestion is to return to the Classic of Changes (易经Yì jīng), to try to understand what the Fire hexagram has to offer, which is adherent and brilliant, composed of two trigrams of Fire (离下、离上 Lí Xià, Li Shàng), therefore the representation of the element in a pure state, thus enabling the understanding of the fundamental characteristics of the Fire Horse that enters in the middle of February. In Richard Wilhelm's interpretation, translated into English by Cary F. Baynes (1989, 118-121), we read that fire is dependent, it is always conditioned to something or someone else, for example to the combustion of Wood, only in this way can it be so alive and bright, and the more it burns, the more it rises from the earth towards the sky. In the judgment of the lines it is informed that if you adhere with perseverance like a cow, you will be guaranteed success (離，利貞，亨。畜牝牛，吉。2) (Zhang, 1995,131). Regarding his image, he appears to illuminate and doubly so, since when he shines he does so for himself and for others (《象》明兩作，離；大人以繼明，照於四方) (Zhang, 1995,135)., just as the sun shines and warms the earth throughout the day. Being a conditioned element, like all others, in a world of interdependence, everything that does not burn positively and for good must be abandoned, just like the ancient Chinese leaders at the end of the dynasties who stopped being model and became capricious and destructive. The positive energy of the Fire Horse is like a beneficent sun that inspires everyone. If you ask the greatest of all Chinese poets, Li Bai (701-762), here in the translation by António Graça de Abreu, in One Hundred Poems of Li Bai 李白诗一百首 what virtues he associates with the horse, we read in response, for example, in “Your bay horse 君马黄” which is friendship and life experience, with its highs and low, but always worthy of being lived in the company of good friends: 君马黄，我马白。 马色虽不同，人心本无隔。 共作游治盘，双行洛阳陌。 长剑既照曜，高冠何赤3赫。 各有千金裘，俱为五侯客。 猛虎落陷阱，壮士时屈厄。 Article Your horse is bay my horse is white. Different color of horses, similar to the hearts of friends. Through the streets of Luoyang we know happy days, sword at waist, tall hats, valuable fur coats. guests of five marquises. Even tigers fall into the trap. Today strong and brave, Tomorrow subject to the misadventures of luck. If such a day happens, Help from a friend. (Abreu, 2021, 174) In a leap forward to contemporary times, we will find in the poet Yao Feng (1958-), in Palavras Cansadas da Gramática (2014), the same traditional reading and an interesting identification with the horse, in “Cavalo Velho”, preserving the idea of friendship that extends throughout the Chinese centuries, but in an inverted presentation of the free condition of the animal, which appears, as happens mutatis mutandis to so many people, sad and imprisoned, unnaturally, in a cart, that is, a social condition, translated into the provision of services to others: Accustomed to the coachman, to passers-by, to cars Forgotten what it's like to gallop Dirty, sagging skin, gloomy as the end of the day Ironed hulls make the trail on the flat Even longer Sitting in a noisy village tavern I saw a horse bent under the weight of the cart Pull up and I would like To tell him in his language: Come in here, old friend, I'll buy you a drink! (Yao, 2014, 122) It is certainly against the essential nature of equids to allow themselves to be imprisoned. They, who love to run freely across the prairies and steppes, through the mountains and valleys, can be domesticated by friendship, suffering and participating in the place of the social order that humans have destined for them. And like people, they also age, losing much of the vigor and energy they were born with, which is reflected in skin that loses its shine and sags. But while they are in the strength of life, and if they are lucky enough to remain free, there is no greater dynamism than theirs. To conclude, my poetic tribute to the Year of the Horse that gallops towards us brimming with strength, enthusiasm and joy: Fire Horse Beautiful, fast, dreamy, Run against the pain, Growing in wind or breeze in the wake of flowers, They dancing in the passage, of paws loaded with earth and heat. Beautiful, fast, dreamy, carry the monkey, And on the back the dragon, they call it the Spirit of the Dragon Horse. 龙马精神 Horse-Dragon Spirit, In a year that brings shine and the light like heralds, sounding strong and loud. item.title: Today Macau
item.description: The Chinese Ministry of Commerce announced yesterday that it is “evaluating” the content and impact of the United States Supreme Court decision on the tariffs imposed by the Donald Trump Administration, reiterating its opposition to “unilateral” measures. In a statement, the ministry indicated that it “took note” of the court decision in the dispute over tariffs and that it is carrying out a “full assessment” of its implications. China “systematically opposes unilateral tariff measures” and reiterates that “the trade war has no winners and protectionism has no way out”, said the ministry, after the United States Supreme Court ruled that the Trump Administration exceeded its powers by invoking the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) as a legal basis to impose tariff rates. The ministry added that the so-called “reciprocal tariffs” and tariffs related to fentanyl constitute ‘unilateral’ measures that, according to Beijing, “not only violate international economic and trade rules”, but also the “domestic law” of the United States, and “do not serve the interests of either party”. Beijing also insists that relations between the two powers must be managed based on cooperation. “The facts have repeatedly demonstrated that China and the United States benefit when they cooperate and are harmed when they confront each other,” said the ministry, which urged Washington to “cancel” the unilateral tariffs imposed on its trading partners. Beijing said it has observed that the United States is “preparing” to resort to alternative measures such as “trade investigations” with the aim of maintaining the imposition of tariffs on its partners, and warned that China will “maintain close surveillance” and “firmly protect” its interests.

item.title: Rota das Letras | Film by Filipa Queiroz tells the story of homeless people from Alta de Coimbra
item.description: “Salatinas – Stories from the Old Alta of Coimbra” brings journalist Filipa Queiroz back to Macau, together with Rafael Vieira and Tiago Cerveira, co-authors of the documentary that is part of the Rota das Letras poster. The film tells the story of how, during the Estado Novo, around three thousand residents were expelled from Alta de Coimbra to allow the construction of the University City The University City in Alta de Coimbra is one of the city's tourist attractions, offering a stunning landscape. However, despite the beauty, the history of the construction of Cidade Universitária is full of suffering. In the documentary “Salatinas – Histórias da Velha Alta de Coimbra”, Filipa Queiroz, Rafael Vieira and Tiago Cerveira tell the story of the people who lived there in the 1940s and who found themselves suddenly homeless and without a plan B. The film is part of the poster for the Rota das Letras Literary Festival, which starts on March 5th. “We hope that, in Macau, the story can have an impact on everyone and in particular on the many people from Coimbra who we know reside in the territory”, Filipa Queiroz, who lived in Macau for several years, told HM and TDM – Macau Television. He is happy to return and to reveal this story unknown to many. And he gives the greatest praise to a festival that saw its birth 15 years ago. "I find the programming of this edition of Rota das Letras particularly courageous and relevant taking into account the contexts of Portugal, Macau and the world at the moment. We try to present the film where it makes sense and this is precisely the case. It is a film about people, but also about power, resistance, identity and the price of progress – themes that Macau knows so well", he highlighted. Filipa Queiroz came into contact with the story of these people through a report. “Rafael Vieira collaborated with me as a journalist, as he ran a publication in Coimbra [Coimbra Coolectiva] and told me that there was an [interesting] story there, and that he wanted to tell stories outside the box, more invisible, so to speak.” “Salatinas” was born, in reference to the name given to the people who lived in Alta de Coimbra, where there were already faculties of Literature, Law and the library. However, the Estado Novo evicted these people to build the currently existing buildings. Three thousand people left their homes, making this “one of the biggest urban transformations in Portugal, at a time when forced evictions, lack of access to housing and social segregation still make headlines”, describes the documentary’s synopsis. “Salatinas” is, therefore, “a trip down memory lane of the historic neighborhood wiped off the map under the regime’s impetus for renewal and the hubbub of students, tricanas, grocers and tailors that hides beneath the colleges”, adds the same synopsis. Leave quickly “What happened was the will of the Government at that time”, says Filipa Queiroz, to explain how a political decision changed the lives of so many people. "The University of Coimbra moved between Lisbon and Coimbra for many years, but then it was located in Coimbra and was the only one in the country, where the country's brains, the elite, were. There was then a decision that the university needed to grow and it had to be there. Salazar himself had studied there [Faculty of Law], in addition to there being a hospital. It wasn't about requalification, but they really destroyed what there was to build on top." What followed was a profound transformation in families in the area. Many never fully recovered. "When the destruction began, basically the Government warned the people who lived there that they all had to get out of there. They gave values ​​to the houses [for compensation], completely disproportionate and much lower than the value of the houses." "There is a person we mention in the film who was part of Salazar's circle, she was a doctor and an illustrious person, and she managed to have her house be one of the last to be removed, but she was still [homeless]. The poorer and more humble the people were, the quicker they had to leave, with one hand in front, the other behind. These people were thrown into neighborhoods of the city, which we can't even call neighborhoods, because it was something improvised at the time", says the co-author of the documentary. We are talking about areas with “fragile” houses. However, the precariousness of housing already came from behind. "Little houses were built that weren't of incredible quality, but the houses in Alta de Coimbra weren't there either, many of them. There was no basic sanitation, that needed to be requalified." A “self-identity” Filipa Queiroz highlights how “the solution was to end everything, not valuing the fact that it is a neighborhood, and with its own identity, and this is the main issue”. The neighborhood was Salatina. "Salatinas are people who worked or lived in the upper part of the city, or who were born there, and who crossed paths daily with the student elite. This diversity was very rich, which ended up having effects on the cultural aspect, on music, for example." Coimbra is a land associated with names in Portuguese music, especially interventionists, such as Zeca Afonso and Carlos Paredes, and among the “doctors” there were also “the futricas”, that is, “the people of Coimbra, but no one ever remembered those people”. Filipa Queiroz highlights that “many people, including those from Coimbra, don’t know what happened there”. “There was a city there, a very concentrated urban network full of people and life, with São João bonfires, cultural events, all very identity-related things.” All things destroyed with the requalification and expansion of the University City. Filipa Queiroz highlights that nowadays, and despite university experiences, the city's Alta no longer has the dynamics it once had. “It has that austere architecture and at night, nothing happens.” “Salatinas” gave voice to a topic that is rarely talked about. "People are very moved and feel very valued. We had people who went to the premiere [in Coimbra, in the Alta area] and who told us: 'It seems that there has been a repair here'. This even led to the death of some people, because they committed suicide out of grief, because they had to leave the place where they built their business and their lives". Filipa Queiroz also thanks Ricardo Pinto, director of Rota das Letras, for the invitation made. "He invited us knowing only the idea of ​​the film. This will allow my colleagues to discover, for the first time, this place, Macau, which is so special to me." Filipa Queiroz wants to continue telling stories through images. Having made documentaries linked to Macau, such as “Boat People” and “Once Upon a Time in Ka-Hó”, the idea is to continue in an audiovisual genre so close to journalism. "Documentaryism adds an artistic layer and time that journalism does not allow. Yes, I would like to make [more documentaries], that is always on my horizon. There are always challenges, with financing the work and the time that can be dedicated to it, but without a doubt, yes, I would like to continue."

item.title: Heritage | Stories of the stores on Rua Cinco de Outubro told in a book
item.description: Natalie Fu has just released a book about traditional commerce on Rua Cinco de Outubro, at the invitation of the Macau Cultural Heritage Reinvention Studies Association. “Macao’s Historical House Taxonomy – The Shophouses at the Rua Cinco de Outubro” tells the centuries-old story of shophouses that were the “heart of Macau’s Chinese community” A book has just been published that reveals a little about the history of commerce carried out by the Chinese community on Rua Cinco de Outubro, located in Porto Interior, the scene of many commercial movements over the centuries. The work also explains how these stores, which are at the same time houses, reveal details about the history of Macau. “Macao’s Historical House Taxonomy – The Shophouses at the Rua Cinco de Outubro”, written by Natalie Fu, a doctoral student at the University of São José, was invited by the Association for Studies on the Reinvention of Cultural Heritage of Macau, whose edition also depends on “the support and assistance of many other people”, the author told HM. One of the book's sales outlets, which does not have a Portuguese version, is Pin-to Livros. “The investigation began with the love for Macau and its old buildings”, reveals the author, who began the research work around these buildings in 2022, in the middle of the pandemic. "Rua de Cinco de Outubro has always been an important commercial area in Macau. Once, it was the heart of Macau's Chinese community. Even today, many old stores remain close to the local neighborhood. The stores are mixed-use buildings", explains the author. This is the stage for commercial diversity, as Rua Cinco de Outubro “is home to several businesses, such as traditional Chinese bakeries, Chinese medicine stores, tea shops and fruit shops”. According to the presentation of the work, made on social media by the association itself, this type of property constitutes “a common type of multifunctional residential building”, where the “plan of the buildings is generally rectangular, with two to three floors”. Typically, the ground floor is used for the store or as a warehouse, while the upper floors are reserved for housing. "This type of construction can adapt to the local climate, presenting great flexibility in the construction methods and materials used. Due to the diversity of daily uses, shop houses were once the main type of building on the streets of Macau, having important historical, social, cultural, architectural and aesthetic value", it further reads. Preservation Challenges Still according to the same note, the book draws attention to the importance of preserving this type of construction and, consequently, a symbol of local heritage. “Unfortunately, because they are small-scale and scattered buildings, and because they are not fully protected by the Macau Heritage Protection Law, they have been gradually disappearing with the rapid development of society”, and, currently, “only a small number of these buildings have the classification of ‘monument’ and are protected”. For Natalie Fu, “the preservation of Macau's stores faces many challenges, one of which is the fact that they are not included in the existing list of protected old buildings in Macau”, in addition to that, in her view, “changes in construction laws have also made it difficult to maintain these old buildings”. Asked about the future of this iconic street in Porto Interior, the author recognizes that “the growth of a city inevitably involves the renovation and disappearance of buildings”, so “determining which buildings should be preserved and how to preserve them is a long-term challenge”. Natalie Fu even talks about the need to extend the investigation to more streets in Macau that are also traditional commercial areas. "Research and documentation of the stores on Rua Cinco de Outubro and in Macau are urgent as their number is dwindling. Additionally, additional academic investigations and discussions with the local community are needed to inform the future direction of the Inner Harbor area." In relation to the panorama on Rua Cinco de Outubro, the author describes that maintenance should be focused on, keeping commercial spaces open. "Stores that are kept in use better highlight their social value. Taking some stores on Rua Cinco de Outubro as an example, the existence of century-old stores further emphasizes the cultural and historical value of the area and the stores. Furthermore, 'keeping them in use' allows for more immediate monitoring and maintenance, which is the most direct way of protecting ancient architecture." A certain influence In a territory characterized by the coexistence of Portuguese and Chinese cultures, Natalie Fu's book shows how these houses were influenced by other cultures. “Chinese and Western architecture in Macau have always influenced each other throughout historical development, and this feature is particularly visible in the appearance of the shop houses.” In this way, this book helps to cement this characteristic, “establishing a classification system for Macau’s shop houses, consolidating their architectural definition”. This book is, therefore, a “classifying study of the old shop houses in Macau”, constituting “the first step towards their safeguarding”, describes, in the same note, the association that supported the editorial and research project. "The author carried out a detailed record and survey [of the stores], starting with visits and cartography surveys in the Porto Interior area. Maps were drawn up of the location of the shop houses on that street, analysis sheets based on fieldwork, photographic records and interviews with current traders and residents, in order to understand the history of the use of each building." Furthermore, the work documents seven cases in particular, “providing information on their history, evolution and current use, as well as a preliminary discussion on possible preservation directions”. The book also records two examples of shop houses that have now disappeared. “It is hoped that this work will encourage more people to discover the ‘beauty of Macau.’ With the shop houses as a central theme, it is expected to promote exchange and discussion between academics from different areas”, the association also points out. Natalie Fu invited “several experts and academics to share their ideas, experiences and suggestions on the protection and future of this type of buildings”, it is described. Born and raised in Macau, Natalie Fu had the opportunity to visit all of Southeast Asia from a young age, trips that led her to “foster a deep appreciation and passion for architecture”. The author has a degree in Architecture, also describing herself as a person interested in the area of ​​heritage conservation and a “historical architecture scholar trained in Macau”.

item.title: Diaspora | Greater connection between Casa de Macau and Casa de Goa defended
item.description: The conference “Casa de Goa and Casa de Macau: fundamental agents of an indispensable dialogue” took place in Lisbon yesterday, which analyzed the connecting role that the entities can have in the Goan and Macau diaspora. Carlos Piteira, president of Casa de Macau, highlights the importance of creating bridges with Casa de Goa through the “parallel representation of Portuguese descendants” What role can Casa de Macau and Casa de Goa, in Lisbon, have, taking into account the passage of time and the developments brought by the new generations of the Macanese and Goan communities? It is true that Macau and Goa have long ceased to be part of the former Portuguese empire, but sociocultural ties remain. With this in mind, the lecture “Casa de Goa and Casa de Macau: fundamental agents of an indispensable dialogue” took place yesterday at the Lisbon Geography Society, which sought to outline answers to the challenges of the future. To HM, Carlos Piteira, president of the Casa de Macau in Lisbon, declared that “it would be interesting if the bridges between the Casa de Macau and the Casa de Goa could also be considered in parallel with their representation of Portuguese descendants and mixed cultures”, taking into account that the two entities “are fundamental pillars for the representation of these communities”. The person responsible, himself Macanese, highlights “the similarities of their gastronomy, Creole and festivities” between the two communities. It would therefore be “interesting to combine the small representations of the giants of the Asian world, represented by the symbolism of the Dragon and the Elephant, as structuring elements for a dialogue between Portugal and Asia, political and institutional wills permit”. In Carlos Piteira's view, the two houses “reinforce the legitimized heritage of the dialogue between the West and the East, and Portugal's centuries-old relations with these countries, often ignored and forgotten by official and institutional powers”. Pedro Colaço, from the management of Casa de Goa, highlights the importance of preserving the memory of the Portuguese presence both in Goa and in the remaining territories of Daman and Diu. "There have been 450 years of history, in the case of Macau it was a few more decades, and we try to keep up with current Goan culture. One of the most important parts of our work is to build a bridge between Goa and Lisbon, and on a daily basis we contact artists, musicians and members of the community, that is our role", he described to HM. Pedro Colaço gave the example of the concert that will take place on March 8th at Fundação Oriente, in Lisbon, entitled “Oscar Castellino – Voz de Ópera de Goa and Piano with Rodrigo Ayala”. Furthermore, Casa de Goa, currently without its own headquarters, seeks, like Casa de Macau, to attract new members, especially from the new generations, in order to continue the project, so that the Casa remains “as a hub of unity for Goans and, increasingly, for friends of Goa”. Follow the story Casa de Macau was founded in Lisbon in 1966 and has followed different phases not only in the history of Portugal but also in the country's relationship with Macau and China. "The existence of the House of Macau undoubtedly marks a parallel with the history of Portugal itself for more than 70 years. Macau was the 'pearl of the East' for the Estado Novo and lived through the turmoil of the revolutionary period of April 1974, adapting and establishing itself as the 'bridge between the West and East'". Finally, after the transition to the People's Republic of China, we have seen the reorganization [of Macau] as a central territory in the connection, from China, with Portuguese-speaking countries.” Carlos Piteira also described that the House of Macau has followed “the history of the times, expanding the vision of the Portuguese presence in this territory”. Furthermore, he had a “no less important” task, having “crystallized, protected and perpetuated the Macanese community in Portugal and the world”. Currently, Casa de Macau has developed several activities that bring more members to Avenida Gago Coutinho, where it is located, and whose building has recently undergone restoration work. Every Wednesday there are Macanese food lunches with Chef Tina, originally from Macau, as well as film sessions and lectures. The Casa's mission is currently “to carry out activities to promote Macau and Macanese culture”, providing “support and promotion of studies and works of scientific content about Macau, Macau people” and also providing “institutional interconnection with other entities linked to Macau, Portugal and Casas de Macau in the diaspora”. Who is from Goa and who is not Pedro Colaço explained that the Goan community in Lisbon “has an easier time talking to the remaining Indian diaspora” in Portugal, taking into account that, for example, “the connection is very old” with the Hindu community. “We are sorry that sometimes [the community] is not talked about more in the media, because it is an important part of Portuguese history”, laments the person in charge, remembering prominent figures in the country, such as António Costa, who was Portuguese prime minister, or Narana Coissoró, former president of Casa de Goa and former deputy of the CDS-PP. “There are more notorious figures, but in general the Goan community has integrated itself very well and is known for being a very educated community”, he also recalled, regretting that in Portugal it is not possible to make a distinction between communities of Indian origin. "One thing that is worrying is the lack of knowledge that exists in relation to the communities. Nowadays there is a lot of pressure due to immigration and then everything gets mixed up", highlights Pedro Colaço, remembering that there is a strong feeling in being Goan, particularly in connection with Catholicism and a very unique culture as opposed to Hindustani communities that are currently very present in Portugal. "The Goan community is so mixed that half of my family, or more, do not appear to be Goan, but I, by chance, do. There is a feeling of being Goan, something that unites us. The other communities of the Indian diaspora are often confessional, they have an associated religion, while the Goan community is, for the most part, Catholic, but everyone goes to their own church, it is very spread out", he pointed out. The future is a challenge Pedro Colaço speaks of a “challenging future” for Casa de Goa. "I'm now in my second term, the leadership has changed president, and one of the things we've been trying to do is to bring young people into the governing bodies. We now have three or four younger members, under the age of 40. We've also been trying to expand the House to non-Goans." In this point, there are similarities with the Casa de Macau, which has also sought to expand the range of members to Chinese or Portuguese people who do not belong to the community. Pedro Colaço adds that, over the years, things have changed. "30 years ago the community was very large, but at this moment, and like all institutions, we have to expand. There are many people who really like Goa and who know a lot about the territory, perhaps even more than me, and they are the ones who have to be pulled", he assumed. Currently, Casa de Goa has 500 members and, even without a headquarters, it seeks to carry out activities, particularly in partnership with Fundação Oriente. A monthly bulletin is published. They no longer have headquarters due to the metro works in Lisbon, which has made the House's agenda difficult. “We are in the process of finding a new headquarters, and it is something that has been a constraint, but we try to carry out as many activities as possible and, every month, we always have activities”, concluded Pedro Colaço.

item.title: UN | Human rights under large-scale attack
item.description: Human rights “are under attack on a large scale throughout the world”, carried out “by those who hold the greatest power” and, sometimes, even “with pride”, denounced the Secretary-General of the United Nations yesterday. "The rule of law is being replaced by the rule of force. And this attack does not come from the shadows nor is it a surprise. It is happening in plain sight and, often, led by those who hold the greatest power. All over the world, human rights are being deliberately and strategically repressed, and sometimes with pride", declared Guterres, speaking in Geneva at the opening session of the 61st session of the UN Human Rights Council. The secretary-general warned that the consequences of this attack “are devastating”, pointing out that people are suffering “twice: first with violence, oppression or exclusion, and then again with the world’s indifference”. "We live in a world where mass suffering is ignored, where human beings are used as bargaining chips, where international law is treated as a mere inconvenience. Conflicts multiply and impunity has become contagious. This is not due to a lack of knowledge, tools or institutions. It is the result of political choices", deplored the former Portuguese Prime Minister. According to António Guterres, “this crisis of respect for human rights is not an isolated case” and “reflects and magnifies all other global fractures”, as “humanitarian needs are exploding, while financing is collapsing”, “inequalities are increasing at an impressive speed, countries are drowning in debt and despair, and climate chaos is accelerating”. The United Nations leader also highlighted that “technology, especially artificial intelligence, is increasingly being used in ways that suppress rights, deepen inequality and expose marginalized people to new forms of discrimination, both online and offline”. "On all fronts, those who are already vulnerable are being pushed further to the margins. And human rights defenders are among the first to be silenced when they try to warn us", he lamented, reinforcing that, "in this coordinated offensive, human rights are the first victims". Deplorable portrait Exposing a devastating portrait at a global level, the UN Secretary-General pointed out that today an “increasing tightening of civic space” is evident, with “journalists and activists imprisoned, NGOs [Non-Governmental Organizations] closed, women's rights in retreat, children's rights ignored, people with disabilities excluded and democracies in erosion”. "The right to peaceful assembly is crushed - and I once again condemn the recent violent crackdown on protests in Iran. Migrants are persecuted, detained and expelled, with complete disregard for their human rights and humanity. Refugees are made into scapegoats. LGBTIQ+ communities are vilified. Minorities and indigenous peoples are targeted. Religious communities are attacked," he continued. Alluding to his personal history, the last time he spoke as secretary-general at the opening of a session of the Human Rights Council, he pointed out that “growing up under the Salazar dictatorship” taught him that “the denial of human rights corrodes all aspects of society. “When the Security Council is paralyzed, when vetoes serve as a political shield, when geopolitical rivalries prevail over the protection of civilians, the result is the same: impunity spreads, suffering multiplies and human rights are trampled on,” he said. “We need a Security Council that reflects the world of today, not the world of 1945,” he added.

item.title: Macau Lawyers Association declares support for the State Security Defense Commission law
item.description: The Macau Lawyers Association, chaired by former deputy Vong Hin Fai, considers the requirements required by the proposed law that will regulate the State Security Defense Commission to be reasonable and necessary. In an opinion article signed by the association, published in the newspaper Ou Mun, the veto on the participation of lawyers in any process considered in any way related to national security is defended. In the text, the association argues that many countries and regions have similar laws, pointing to the examples of the Special Advocate Statute in the United Kingdom and Canada, the classified information procedures law in the United States of America and the regulation of legal practitioners in Hong Kong. All the regimes mentioned by AAM are based on legal systems of the Common Law style, the British tradition, which contrasts with the reality of Macau, which adopts a legal system of the so-called continental tradition, with roots in Germany and France and which also applies to Portugal. Full support The association also said that it agrees and supports the proposed law, as it considers that it advances and improves the commission's duties and competencies while “fully applying the general perspective of national security”. The association also cites the justification note to emphasize that “the defense of State security constitutes a constitutional responsibility of the Macao SAR”. The Macau Lawyers Association also highlighted that Macau must “implement the decisions and instructions of the Central Government within the scope of national security” and that this proposed law, by strengthening the powers of the commission, will maintain “coherence with the norms of the Hong Kong national security law” and “coordinate with the Electoral Law for the Chief Executive and the Electoral Law for the Legislative Assembly”.

item.title: Security | Macao SAR rulers applaud White Paper on Hong Kong
item.description: China has released a new White Paper on national security, on Hong Kong, which is entitled “Practice of Safeguarding National Security in Hong Kong under ‘One Country, Two Systems.’ In the Macao SAR, secretaries and political leaders reacted positively, saying that the document provides guarantees of stability and is a reference for Macau Days after the conviction in Hong Kong of Jimmy Lai, a media entrepreneur who founded the now-defunct Apple Daily newspaper, China launches a new White Paper focused on the need to safeguard national security in neighboring territory. The “Practice of Safeguarding National Security in Hong Kong under ‘One Country, Two Systems'” was published by the Communication Department of China's State Council on Tuesday. According to the Xinhua news agency, this White Paper consists of five parts, detailing “the persistent struggle to safeguard national security in Hong Kong and the fundamental responsibility of the Central Government in national security matters related to Hong Kong”. In the same note, it is explained that the White Paper “exposes the achievements of the HKSAR in fulfilling its constitutional responsibility to safeguard national security” and also “Hong Kong’s transition from chaos to stability and prosperity”. “Efforts to create high-standard security in order to promote the high-quality development of the ‘One Country, Two Systems’ policy” are not forgotten, in addition to explaining that “the Central Government has applied a holistic approach to national security”. In this context, “it effectively exercised general jurisdiction over the HKSAR, in accordance with the country's Constitution and the Basic Law of the HKSAR”, and the Law on Safeguarding National Security “has been applied in the region” and has ensured “that Hong Kong is administered by patriots”. On the Macao SAR side, the government apparatus reacted positively to this White Paper, after the bill that presents a new format and composition of the Macao SAR State Security Defense Commission, created in 2018, was generally approved in the Legislative Assembly. Chan Tsz King, Secretary for Security, was one of the political figures who reacted to the document, which considers “ensuring the stable and lasting implementation” of the “One Country, Two Systems” principle. Quoted in an official note, the secretary understands that the White Paper comes to “clarify the intrinsic unity between political principles and institutional logic, causing Hong Kong society to return to normality and order to be restored”. The document, in the secretary's view, “serves as an important reference for the Macao SAR to review and improve the construction of its legal system in the context of defending the security of the State and the respective execution mechanism”. Chan Tsz King highlights that his leadership will give “great importance to ensuring security in non-traditional areas under the new situation, establishing the long-term stability of the Macao SAR as a strategic objective”. Firm as a rock Also according to Xinhua, the White Paper describes how Beijing “supports the HKSAR in fulfilling its constitutional responsibility to safeguard national security by effectively preventing, interrupting and punishing any activities that put national security at risk”. “The efforts” of the neighboring region to safeguard national security aim, according to the same document, to “sustain and develop” the principle created by Beijing to support Taiwan and the two special administrative regions, without forgetting the protection of “fundamental human rights, dignity and well-being of the 7.5 million residents of Hong Kong”. The White Paper released by the State Council also states that “in today's world, and with unprecedented global transformations that have occurred in a century, they are accelerating, with the development environment facing China undergoing profound and complex changes”. In this way, “safeguarding national security is a long-term and permanent task”, it is said. The White Paper states that Hong Kong “enjoys a high standard of security”, with the region “fated to overcome all risks and challenges in the future journey, remaining as stable as a rock in a turbulent world”. Another political figure from the Macao SAR who reacted was Adriano Marques Ho, director-general of the Customs Service, saying that the White Paper “has an important guiding significance and a profound impact for the complete and accurate implementation of ‘One Country, Two Systems’ in the Hong Kong and Macau regions, for the realization of long-term prosperity and stability, and for their stable and sustainable progression”. Adriano Marques Ho added that “both Hong Kong and Macau are inalienable and sacred parts of China”, and Beijing “has firmly and consistently maintained national sovereignty, security and development interests”. In the view of the top Customs official, “the external hostile forces and anti-China elements disturbing Hong Kong incited and created the ‘legislative review riots’, which ended up evolving into a ‘color revolution’ version of Hong Kong, seriously damaging the constitutional order and the rule of law in Hong Kong, and putting national sovereignty, security and development interests at risk”. End of the “chaotic situation” Lam, Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, said the White Paper “comprehensively analyzes and outlines Hong Kong's journey in defending national security, major achievements and experience gained”. In the governor's view, “Hong Kong went from a chaotic situation to stability and prosperity”. In the case of Macau, the principles contained in the White Paper apply, with the secretary promising to “continue to intensify education, giving priority to the formation of a social base that supports the values ​​of love for the country and for Macau”. In this context, the aim is to “develop a comprehensive educational system to increase the patriotic feeling of young people and consolidate the ideological foundation of national security through multidimensional educational activities and exchanges”. It is promised that the Social Affairs and Culture department “will continue to promote national security using culture as a driving force, reinforcing the exploration and dissemination of Macau’s historical and cultural resources and organizing different types of exhibitions and cultural shows with unique characteristics”. The idea is to “spread the excellent Chinese cultural heritage in order to resist the erosion of harmful cultures, reinforce the cultural and national identity of the population and unite the forces of different sectors of society through culture”. Wong Sio Chak, Secretary for Administration and Justice, who for years held the Security portfolio, considers that the White Paper has “extreme relevance for Macao SAR issues relating to the defense of national security”, particularly with regard to “defending sovereignty, security and the development interests of the State”. The promises are that the area of ​​Administration and Justice “will boost legislative production in the priority areas related to the defense of State security, continuing to improve the respective legal regime”, with “training courses on the Constitution, the Basic Law and legislation relating to the defense of State security aimed at public service workers at different levels”. In turn, Tai Kin Ip, Secretary for Economy and Finance, described that “economic and financial security constitute non-traditional key domains among the twenty priority areas of the global vision of national security, and are also crucial factors in ensuring the stable development and long-term security of Macau and the country”. Tai Kin Ip aims to “pragmatically promote the development of adequate diversification of the economy, strengthening Macau’s global economic resilience and maintaining a high level of attention to various risks and challenges in the economic and financial domain”. Raymond Tam, Secretary for Transport and Public Works, said Macau must “cultivate an awareness of vigilance in times of peace, in order to consolidate the foundations of lasting stability and security”. In this sense, the government official understands that “Macau must always put the safeguarding of the sovereignty, security and development interests of the State first”, and in terms of Transport and Public Works he promises to “persist in the predominance of Executive power, firmly integrating the safeguarding of national security in all tasks”. Ao Ieong Seong, Commissioner against Corruption, believes that “the security and stability of the political environment and the good functioning of the system, with the predominance of the Executive branch, [guarantees that] the level of governance in the Macao SAR is increasingly higher”.
