The commissioner highlighted “last year’s successful holding of the elections for the 8th Legislative Assembly, reinforcing the implementation of the principle of ‘Macau governed by patriots’ and effectively ensuring the lasting stability of the Macao SAR”.

item.title: Security Committee | Jurists warn of contradiction to the Basic Law
item.description: Despite support for national security issues, the requirements of the State Security Defense Commission's proposed law are considered contrary and incomprehensible in light of Macau's legal framework Analysts interviewed by Lusa consider the proposed law for the Commission for the Defense of State Security, voted yesterday in the Legislative Assembly, to be unconstitutional, highlighting “disturbing aspects”, such as restrictions on the appointment of lawyers in national security cases. The proposed law that will frame the State Security Defense Commission (CDSE) was discussed and voted on in general by deputies to the Legislative Assembly yesterday. The document, according to Macau-based lawyer Luís Almeida Pinto, “contains disturbing aspects of the constitutional functioning of various powers, and also in some matters of rights, freedoms and guarantees enshrined in the Macau ‘Constitution’: the Basic Law”. Anticipating changes to the Basic Law of the Judicial Organization, the proposal determines that the choice of a lawyer for national security cases is subject to the approval of a judge, who forwards the request to the CDSE, so that it can issue a binding and non-appealable opinion. Special authorization, the Government proposes, can occur in criminal or other proceedings, when “there are well-founded reasons to believe that there is a need to protect the interests of State security”. Almeida Pinto evokes the Basic Law, which guarantees “access to the Law, the courts, and assistance from a lawyer in the defense of their legitimate rights and interests”, to point out that it is up to the defendant “to freely choose the lawyer who best serves them”. “It seems like a rule that will be unconstitutional when approved, and when applied in practice”, he explains. Collision with Lawyer's Statute In addition to being “a violation of the Basic Law”, with constitutional force in Macau, Pedro Leal, who has practiced law in the territory for several decades, points out “clearly, a collision” between what is proposed and “the decree that regulates the Lawyers Association and the Statute” of the Lawyer, with regard to the free choice of a defender. This is the “most debatable issue” of the proposal, assumes Leal, who says he agrees with the legislative initiative. "China pays special attention to security issues, it is a world power, as such it does not want interference in any way. I understand the position and I understand that it does not want changes to the 'status quo'. (…) Now, they want to do things, do them well", he adds. Speaking to Lusa, Almeida Pinto also considers the regime envisaged to be “unacceptable” for “inquiries to be made to lawyers” who wish to legally represent a defendant in national security cases. Attached to the request made by the agents to the judge, there must be, among other elements, information regarding the members of the lawyer's household, nationality and connection with organizations or individuals abroad. This is a “true investigation into personal life”, when “what is only at stake is the exercise of the profession for which he is duly registered and authorized by the Macau Lawyers Association”, he says. The requirement, “in addition to being extremely vague, is perfectly impossible” to implement, assesses Leal, who suggests “it is implicit” that a non-Chinese lawyer will not be authorized representation in these cases – it should be noted that in cases of national security, only the intervention of Chinese judges is now permitted. Question of times Another doubt, raised to Lusa by jurist António Katchi, concerns the time it will take for the CDSE to issue the opinion. The proposal does not clarify this aspect, so the Code of Administrative Procedure “should” be applied, which sets the deadline for acts to be carried out by administrative bodies at 15 days. But, says Katchi, “will the CDSE follow this same understanding or will it consider (without the possibility of this being denied by any court) that it can simply leave the issue to its next semi-annual ordinary meeting?”. If the opinion is negative and it is necessary to repeat the process, with a new legal representative, “how many months or years will the defendant remain deprived of his liberty, without a lawyer”? Alluding to the principle of judicial independence, which he recalls is guaranteed by the Basic Law, António Katchi deduces “with complete certainty, the inadmissibility of subjecting a judicial decision to a binding opinion from an administrative body, namely the CDSE”. The professor also talks about the importance of a relationship of trust between constituent and lawyer and “how vital it is, for a person at risk of a prison sentence, to be defended by a lawyer who is sincerely motivated by the cause and well versed in the matter involved”. In addition to the Basic Law and the Joint Declaration, signed by Lisbon and Beijing in 1987, and which defined rules for Macau after the transition of administration, Katchi highlights another legal provision that the proposal contradicts: the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), according to which, he quotes, “every person accused of a crime shall have the right, in full equality, (…) to present himself at trial and to defend himself in person or to be assisted by a defender of your choice.” The ICCPR is one of the instruments that constitute the UN International Bill of Human Rights. In 1992, when Macau was still a territory administered by Portugal, Lisbon extended this convention to the region. Although China signed the treaty in 1998, it never ratified it, and is not bound by its rules. The Basic Law, explains António Katchi, points out that restrictions on fundamental rights, including the right to be assisted by a lawyer, “cannot contradict the provisions of the ICCPR”.

item.title: National security | Defended legal basis for the absence of defense
item.description: Wang Yu, professor at the Faculty of Law of the University of Macau, argued in an opinion article in the newspaper Ou Mun that the fact that decisions and opinions of the MSAR State Security Defense Commission cannot be appealed are well supported legally. The proposed law for its reformulation is currently under special analysis in the Legislative Assembly. The academic also argues that the lack of appeal has a constitutional basis, referring to the cases of France and the USA, where there is a regime in which the courts do not have jurisdiction over disputes arising from political issues. He also argues that, in the world, there is a general consensus on the fact that highly political acts cannot be prosecuted in ordinary courts. Wang Yu also spoke of the basic law of the judicial organization of Macau, which determines that “issues of a political nature” are excluded from administrative, tax and customs litigation, as well as “acts carried out in the exercise of political functions and liability for damages resulting from that exercise”. This means, for the professor, that the courts cannot deal with acts arising from the exercise of political functions.

item.title: Natural Gas | Renminbi worth new price cuts
item.description: The devaluation of the currency led the Government to announce yesterday the third annual cut in the price of natural gas, with the reduction varying between 0.56 percent and 0.96 percent. With the new cuts, all prices are below the values ​​of 2022, the year before the invasion of Ukraine and a general rise in the cost of gas Since yesterday, the price of natural gas has been reduced by between 0.56 percent and 0.96 percent. The announcement was made yesterday morning, through a statement from the Directorate of Environmental Protection Services (DSPA). “In response to the decline in the international price of natural gas in recent years and fluctuations in the exchange rate of the renminbi in relation to the pataca, the cost of purchasing natural gas to supply Macau has fallen”, it was justified. “The sales prices of natural gas charged to the four groups of customers decreased by around 0.6 percent to 1 percent”, it was added. With the changes, residential customers, the so-called Group A, will have the smallest reduction, of 0.56 percent, with the price dropping to 6.7403 patacas per cubic meter of gas, compared to 6.7782 patacas per cubic meter of gas. In relation to Group B of natural gas consumers, non-commercial residents, the cut is 0.59 percent, to 6.3786 patacas per cubic meter, when previously the price was 6.4165 patacas per cubic meter. In Group C, large customers, a cut of 0.60 percent is applied, to 6.3198 patacas per cubic meter, from 6.3568 patacas per cubic meter. The biggest reduction targets Group D of customers, also known as “special”, who will benefit from a price cut of 0.96 percent, to 3.9447 patacas per cubic meter. Until yesterday, the price was .9825 patacas per cubic meter. Before the war With the new prices coming into force, the cost of natural gas is below 2022 levels, even before the Ho Iat Seng Government announced increases of 8.2 percent to 14.3 percent, an indirect consequence of Russia's invasion of Ukraine and a spike in demand in international markets. Before this increase, residential customers paid MOP6.9998 per cubic meter, while Group B customers paid MOP6.4122 per cubic meter, Group C customers paid MOP6.3364 per square meter and Group D customers paid MOP4.0126 per cubic meter. The annual price reductions since the 2023 increase contributed to the new reality, with the cuts varying between 3.14 percent and 8.13 percent, with the changes being justified by the devaluation of the renminbi, the Macao SAR supply market, and also international prices.

item.title: Game | Dealers will operate exchange offices
item.description: The concessionaires Galaxy, Melco and SJM were authorized to carry out, “at their own risk and expense”, foreign exchange trading in the casinos and Mocha rooms they operate, according to orders signed by Sam Hou Fai, published yesterday in the Official Bulletin. The orders of the Chief Executive come into force today. Therefore, Galaxy Casino will be able to operate exchange offices in Star World, Galaxy Macau, Broadway and Waldo. Melco Resorts will be able to exchange currency at the Altira, City of Dreams, Studio City casinos and the Mocha rooms at Golden Dragon, Hotel Grand Drangon, Hotel Royal, Hotel Sintra, Kuong Fat and Porto Interior. Finally, SJM Resorts is authorized to operate exchange offices in the casinos Lisboa, Grand Lisboa, Grand Lisboa Palace, Le Royal Arc, as well as the Oceanus spaces in Pelota Basca, Landmark, Grandview, Kam Pek Paradise, Casa Real, Emperar Palace, Ponte 16 and Legend Palace.

item.title: AL | Project presented that reduces Government interventions
item.description: The Rules and Mandates Committee presented a bill to reduce Government interventions during oral interpellation sessions. The option reduces the Executive's intervention by five minutes and adds more questions in a block The Legislative Assembly (AL) Rules and Mandates Committee presented a bill that will reduce the time for Executive interventions. The project with the changes was published on the hemicycle portal. According to the current model, when a deputy makes an oral question, members of the Executive have an initial response period of 10 minutes. After the first explanations, the deputy responsible for the interpellation may make a new intervention, to ask for additional clarifications. The Government's second response follows, which can last for five minutes. Once the interaction between the deputy responsible for the oral interpellation and the Government is over, the other deputies are authorized to intervene. The legislators' interventions are collected as a block, with the Executive having the right to a last 10-minute intervention, in which it can answer the questions. However, with the new proposal, the Government will have five minutes less to answer questions and the intervention in response to the request for clarification from the deputy who asked the initial questions will be concentrated with questions from other deputies. With the new model, members of the Executive only have to intervene twice, the first time to respond to the deputy and a second time to provide additional clarifications to that deputy and to answer questions from other legislators. Currently, they intervene three times. Joint interpellations The new project also changes the way oral interpellations signed by more than one deputy are conducted, a mechanism little used by the Legislative Assembly. According to the new project, when an oral interpellation is signed by more than one deputy, everyone will have the opportunity to ask for extra clarification, after the first intervention by members of the Executive. This is a different reality from the current one, in which only the first subscriber has the opportunity to intervene to ask for additional clarification. The second and subsequent signers cannot intervene either in the clarification phase or in the phase open to all other deputies. “The change that the Commission suggests to the Deputies ensures that all Deputies have the possibility of intervening in all interpellations, simultaneously allowing the Government to respond in a concentrated manner and at a single moment to all the questions raised”, was justified by the commission led by José Chui Sai Peng. Members of the Rules and Mandates Committee also include deputies Iau Teng Pio, Ângela Leong, Wong Kit Cheng, Song Pek Kei, Ip Sio Kai and Lei Wun Kong. Deputy card with changes The Rules and Mandates Committee proposed changes to the deputies' cards. According to the new model, the card now includes that Macau is a region of the People's Republic of China. Previously, the words People's Republic of China were only written in Chinese and within the Macao SAR symbol.

item.title: STD | Portuguese market is a priority
item.description: The director of the Tourism Services (DST), Maria Helena de Senna Fernandes, said that Portugal will be one of Macau's priorities when it comes to attracting more foreign visitors. In a message broadcast by public broadcaster TDM – Teledifusao de Macau, regarding the Lunar Year of the Fire Horse, Senna Fernandes pointed out among the targets for this year “European markets, such as Portugal and Spain”. The director also mentioned Southeast Asia, Northeast Asia – a region that includes Japan, Mongolia and the Far East of Russia – and “the emerging tourist markets in the Middle East and Central Asia”. Senna Fernandes predicted that Macau will receive 41 million visitors in 2026, after reaching close to 40.1 million visitors last year, a new historic high. The majority (90.6 percent) of tourists came from Mainland China or Hong Kong. Tourism | Flat orders to encourage consumption Deputy Chan Lai Kei wants the Government to draw lessons from tourism statistics and visitor consumption patterns to implement measures that increase tourists' stay in Macau and commerce in residential neighborhoods off the tourist trail. In a written question, the deputy linked to the Fujian community indicated that during this Lunar New Year, the Government invested a lot of resources into organizing large events, which failed to benefit small and medium-sized companies in areas less popular with tourists. Chan Lai Kei argues that the Government should improve the transport system during national holiday periods, in order to facilitate visits to residential neighborhoods, far from the most popular tourism centers. The deputy also asked the Sam Hou Fai Executive for practical measures to improve the experiences of international tourists and eliminate current obstacles, such as the lack of international electronic payments and language barriers. Performance Venue | IC will launch new measures The president of the Cultural Affairs Bureau (IC), Deland Leong, revealed that the IC will launch an online platform for companies to consult rental requests for the Macau Open-Air Performance Venue. The changes are part of the Government's objectives to “expand and reinforce the functions” of the concert venue and were revealed on the morning program Forum Macau on the Chinese channel Rádio Macau. This objective had previously been revealed by the secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, during the presentation of the Lines of Government Action, in the Legislative Assembly. At that time, the secretary pointed out that in the future the space could receive 3×3 basketball courts or other facilities for family sporting activities. Deland Leong also acknowledged that the Government will review some of the regulations and guidelines for the use of the space.

item.title: Borders | Secretary wants security against external forces
item.description: The Secretary for Security promised that the region will strengthen border security in 2026, “to avoid interference from external forces”. Chan Tsz King highlighted the importance of collaboration with secret agencies in Mainland China and Hong Kong The Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, committed to strengthening security at Macau's border posts throughout this year, “to avoid interference from external forces”, but without pointing out any threats. “We will further enhance security surveillance at sea and land ports to prevent interference from external forces,” Chan told public broadcaster TDM – Teledifusao de Macau. In a message regarding the Lunar Year of the Fire Horse, which began last week, the leader did not identify the threats coming from abroad, but promised to “fully safeguard national security”. “We will continue to strengthen our intelligence collection and analysis capabilities, especially through ongoing intelligence exchanges with mainland China and Hong Kong,” Chan Tsz King also said. In November, the secretary promised to create, in 2026, a risk warning system against national security and warned against “acts of interference and destruction” by “external forces”. Dangerous discord On July 31, Macau police announced the arrest of former deputy Au Kam San, a Portuguese citizen, in the first case under the national security law. On February 5, the director of the Judicial Police assured journalists that there was sufficient evidence to justify Au Kam San's arrest. “There is a lot of evidence and we are entering the trial process, so we cannot disclose the details,” said Sit Chong Meng. Three days earlier, human rights organization Human Rights Watch said Au Kam San's case illustrates the “erosion of autonomy and fundamental freedoms” in Macau. In November, the head of the European Union (EU) Delegation in Hong Kong and Macau wrote on social media that he had met with Macau's Secretary for Economy and Finance, Anton Tai Kin Ip. “I also expressed concern about political issues,” added Briton Harvey Rouse. But the EU representation declined to reveal to Lusa whether the case against Au Kam San was mentioned at the meeting. In September, during a visit to Macau, Prime Minister Luís Montenegro admitted that he did not discuss the detention of the Portuguese citizen with the territory's leader, Sam Hou Fai. “There are some issues that also deserve some modesty in their treatment and this is one of them”, defended the prime minister.

item.title: Taxis | Women want the Government to control applications
item.description: The Women's Association argues that the use of online platforms to hail taxis should be subject to a permanent control mechanism by the Government. The opinion is contained in a document released on Friday, by the association that has two representatives in the Legislative Assembly, at a time when Uber, a non-Chinese application, began operating in the Macao SAR. The association states that the objective would be to allow the Government to know in real time the needs for taxis in the territory, through the use of artificial intelligence technologies. Focusing on peak hours and holidays, the approach will enable coordination with platform operators to dynamically allocate transport capacity, improving cross-district coverage and reducing taxi downtime. The “systemic approach will increase the operational efficiency of taxis”, it was argued.

item.title: Advertising or Exclusion of Advertising from the Beginning to the Judgment of Cases
item.description: By Iau Teng Pio Deputy Director of the Faculty of Law of the University of Macau ​This text discusses the limits of advertising and its exclusion from the beginning of the process until the trial. It was prepared taking into account the application of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (hereinafter “ICCPR”) ex vi Basic Law of Macau, and the protection of legal assets, clarifying that the principle of exclusion of publicity is not equivalent to secrecy, in conjunction with international experience and legislation relating to Macau. I. The pillar of the ICCPR: The legal limits of advertising and its exclusion ​Article 14 of the ICCPR established the core of the publicity of processes in which the general rule is the principle of publicity, with its exclusion being exceptional, and even though all sentences and rulings must be public. The essential value of the public trial lies in guaranteeing the public's right to information and judicial transparency, preventing abuse of power. The exclusion of advertising must be based on a legal basis, including public morals, public order, national security, the interest of the private life of the parties concerned, etc., always restricted to the “limits of necessity and appropriateness”. Publicity of sentences is a necessary guarantee of judicial credibility. Only in rare cases involving the interests of minors may restrictions be imposed on certain content, with no exception to total exclusion. II. Balance of legal interests: The essential orientation of advertising values ​​and their exclusion ​The distinction between advertising and its exclusion essentially lies in the balance of different legal interests. Open trials, through procedural transparency, not only ensure public oversight of the judiciary, but also provide a fair judicial environment for defendants or parties, and also serve as a form of judicial education and social deterrence, thus safeguarding public interests and the rule of law. The purpose of exclusion from advertising is to protect higher-level legal interests, including national security, the private life of the parties, the legitimate interests of minors, commercial secrets, etc. Its application must strictly adhere to the principles of legality, necessity and proportionality, and cannot be arbitrarily expanded. III. Procedural limit: Exclusion from advertising is not equivalent to secrecy ​The “exclusion of advertising” in a process only concerns the participation of the public and the media, as well as the disclosure of information to these subjects, so it is not an absolute secret. The essential protection consists of the mandatory intervention of defenders (especially lawyers): whether it is confidentiality during the investigation phase or the exclusion of publicity during the trial phase, the defender and the legal representative of the offended party have different procedural rights, including, among others, the right to meet with their clients, to communicate, to consult the files, to investigate and produce evidence, as well as to participate in debates. Its intervention serves both to supervise the exercise of judicial power and to protect the legitimate rights and interests of the parties, maintaining a balance in the structure of accusation, defense and trial, and preventing “secret negotiations”. This is the main foundation of fair process to the exclusion of advertising. IV. International practice: Common practices and adaptation to differences in various States ​Diferentes Estados têm estabelecido, geralmente, a “regra geral de publicidade, a sua exclusão como uma excepção, e a obrigatoriedade de publicidade das decisões judiciais”. The difference lies mainly in the definitions and scope of discretion to opt out of advertising. Common law systems (such as those in the USA, the United Kingdom and Canada) are mainly based on discretion, with exceptions that consider the public interest; Civil law systems (such as those in France and Germany) are mainly based on the legal exclusion of advertising, with strictly limited exceptions. The EU requires that court decisions be made public only after private information has been withheld. Despite the different models, they all include state secrecy, as well as the interests of private life and minors as essential circumstances for the exclusion of publicity. And they all guarantee the right of lawyers to participate in closed proceedings. V. Legal regime of Macau: A system of local practice in accordance with the ICCPR ​The current procedural regime in Macau adopts a model of “general rule of advertising and its exclusion as an exception”, in accordance with the ICCPR. For example, in the investigation and trial phases the principle of judicial secrecy applies, binding people with access to case information, preventing actions detrimental to the investigation. But it does not prevent the participation of qualified defenders, in accordance with the law, and also the participation of the offended, when duly represented by lawyers, as assistants. In the circumstances provided for by law, when the criminal proceedings stipulated in the current Law on the Defense of State Security involve actions that would harm the interests of national security if conducted publicly, the competent judges may determine the exclusion of certain procedural acts from publicity. Regardless of whether the procedures are public or not, sentences must be announced publicly, strictly respecting the principle that “exclusion from publicity does not equal secrecy”, thus guaranteeing judicial efficiency and safeguarding procedural justice. Publicity and its exclusion from processes are not contradictory ideas, but rather related to the fundamental objective of true justice, the core of which is the balance between the protection of different legal interests. Practice in the various States and in Macau demonstrate that the application of the principle of exclusion from advertising must be strictly legal and appropriate, protecting specific legal interests and avoiding, at the same time, excessive sacrifice of judicial transparency. The Macau model, which provides for the “general rule of publicity + exception to exclusion + possible intervention of defenders + publicity of sentences”, is not only in accordance with the spirit of the ICCPR, but also adapts to local judicial traditions, constituting a practical reference model for the balance between publicity and secrecy in judicial proceedings.

item.title: Total unconsciousness
item.description: 19 dead following the bad weather recorded in Portugal for two weeks. 19? It's true, unfortunately there were two more deaths due to total unconsciousness last week. On the second day of Storm Kristin, the waters of the Mondego River began to rise and the worst was expected. The river's flow began to flood several lands and invade several roads. Mr. Venâncio and Ms. Fátima, residents near Soure, in the municipality of Montemor-o-Velho, decided to take their Citroen and go to Coimbra for a medical appointment, when the municipal authorities were already starting to warn people not to leave their homes. It was a Tuesday and in the afternoon Civil Protection announced that several regional roads were closed to traffic because of the floods that were progressing due to the increase in the flow of the Mondego River. Mr. Venâncio, aged 68, and his wife, aged 65, finished their hospital appointment in Coimbra and decided to return home. They still had dinner in the student city at a family member's house, but they didn't want to stay the night in the house where they were staying or spend 70 or 80 euros on a hotel room. They even decided to return home, despite having finished watching on television during dinner that the roads around Montemor-o-Velho were dangerous. There they went. At one point, Mr. Venâncio called a friend saying that he wasn't orienting himself very well on which route to take and that the road he was on was unfamiliar to him. The friend understood that Mr. Venâncio would be lost, because he shouldn't even be behind the wheel due to having recently had some mental disorders that could indicate some type of dementia. Mr. Venâncio's total unconsciousness caused him to enter a road that was already covered in water and the car slid into a rice field that was already completely flooded. Hours passed and the couple's daughter began to get worried, her parents' cell phones were not responding and she decided to alert the police authorities. From then on, for almost a week, the television channels only reported that a couple was missing. The searches were incessant. A huge effort by divers and maritime patrols, firefighters and GNR soldiers. Days later and after the water level began to drop, some hikers saw the roof of a car immersed in the rice field and alerted the authorities. The confirmation deeply saddened the population of Varride, where Mr. Venâncio and Ms. Fátima lived. Their bodies were inside the Citroen and the number of flood victims was 19. Now, it is time for reconstruction in several affected areas, especially in Leiria and Marinha Grande. In the debate in the Assembly of the Republic with the presence of the Government, the Prime Minister announced his full support for the victims of the calamity, despite there still being many people who did not receive government support and who were left with nothing in the latest fires. An important note: the exemplary work of the president of Coimbra City Council. Ana Abrunhosa received the greatest praise from all quarters, except from the Chega party, because Abrunhosa was not a populist and a demagogue. The district of Leiria was the area most affected by the storms and where there was the greatest destruction, where between five and eight million trees fell, but we can announce first-hand that the city council of Leiria has already invited a personality who left behind vast and commendable work in the afforestation of Macau while he lived in the former Portuguese colony. Engineer António Paula Saraiva was invited to study the reconstruction of the main garden in front of the City Hall and where almost all the trees fell due to strong gusts of wind. António Saraiva has already visited the site and was immediately ready to study the arboreal reconstruction of the Leiriense garden. A round of applause for this exceptional technician, who, despite being retired, was immediately ready to cooperate for the well-being of the people of Leiria who like to visit his main garden. Reconstruction of the destroyed areas will be hard and expensive work. It could exceed 10 billion euros, but as Luís Montenegro said in Parliament, it will have to be a reconstruction carried out by all Portuguese. The country continues, life does not stop, but we hope that promises do not fail, as has been recorded in other cases. Portugal was in the news for the worst reasons contemplated by natural phenomena, but Portugal will be in the news again when it can announce to the world that the Portuguese people affected by a calamity have returned to their normal lives.

item.title: You need to know how to govern
item.description: On the day the Minister of Internal Administration took office, we spoke to a commander of the National Republican Guard (GNR) who told us “Oh, my dear, this minister Maria Lúcia Amaral is going to be a disaster... you are a very good jurist, but you don't have the slightest ability to deal with men with wiry beards, nor do you have the slightest idea of ​​what the security forces are and what needs to change in such a disturbed and obscure panorama”. The commander was right. The minister was a black page of the current Government and ended up resigning in times of calamity. He had to resign forcibly. He was already a “jester” within the PSP, GNR and Civil Protection. You left the country stunned when it was only three days after Storm Kristin hit Leiria and Marinha Grande that you came out to say… nothing! Several politicians and television commentators had long ago called for the Prime Minister to replace the Minister of Internal Affairs. Luís Montenegro turned a deaf ear and the result was the same as the catastrophe that has hit the national territory. Montenegro looked around at his friends and did not immediately find a new minister for such an important portfolio. Montenegro does not have a vision of reality. By the way, Portugal has a personality who should immediately be invited, if he were willing, to occupy the position of Minister of Internal Administration. Only Admiral Gouveia e Melo knows how to coordinate the Armed Forces with the GNR, PSP, Fire Department and Civil Protection. And it was seen in the Covid-19 pandemic. We did not vote for presidential candidate Gouveia e Melo, but we recognize his stance as an organizer, coordinator and with seriousness in taking the position of Minister of Internal Administration in difficult times for the country, which finds itself from North to South in a situation of tragedy. Last week, the unimaginable happened. No one, much less an infrastructure official, ever thought that the country's main highway, the A1 that connects Lisbon to Porto, could collapse due to the rupture of a dike on the Mondego River. In the Coimbra area, motorists will be unable to use the highway for months. We always come back to the same thing: we need to know how to govern. And the Government, at the beginning of the storms that have ravaged the country, was not up to the tragic events. It did not even include the storage of a substantial amount of generators in the planning for a new blackout or other type of catastrophe. It would be the least. More than 20,000 Portuguese people are still without electricity, two weeks after the first storm that knocked down power poles and flooded gas stations. The truth is that thousands of Portuguese people have been displaced from their homes and evacuated from villages surrounded by water. In the Coimbra area, the marines never stop transporting people, food and other goods in their amphibious vehicles for a day. There are people who are left with nothing. A life to build a house and from one day to the next they found themselves completely without what they had gathered for years. The lands in various parts of the country are saturated with water and in the near future, according to experts, these lands will collapse and the houses that are in their path will be destroyed. Even in Porto Brandão, next to Trafaria, and in Costa de Caparica, the cliff collapses left hundreds of people homeless. And for years, the Almada City Council did not foresee that the tragedy could happen? We have many competent mayors in Portugal, but we also have incompetent and corrupt ones who only care about building roundabouts and other megalomaniac works for the Spanish to see. The reconstruction of this calamity that hit Portugal will take years and one of the most important works, the installation of underground electrical lines, has already received the “solidarity” verdict from the European Union: it does not grant support for this. And this is how the Portuguese are witnessing a flooded country, with agriculture destroyed, with houses and factories that have disappeared and with an endless line of trucks that transport much of what feeds the population, due to a highway viaduct that collapsed, and who knows how it was built... we just hope that in the future they will know how to govern with the aim of providing the Portuguese with a better and more peaceful life.

item.title: Camões, the maricón
item.description: He was a Christian, baptized António and was born on the island of Java, hence the gentile name Jau, who gives his name to a street in Lisbon, at the intersection of that of the Lusíadas. Luís Vaz would have met this new friend of his following a shipwreck in Cambodia – perhaps when he passed through the land of “loving Malays, brave Jaus” (X.44.4,7) coming from Macau, where he had never been. Or while waiting for a ship to take him to Cochin and then to Goa, around 1565. Or he actually met him in Goa, the Sodom of the East. From that moment on, António would not let go of him until Luís died. He expired in the arms of his slave. This is the myth, of course. The only historical sources we have are the first Camonian biographers, Pedro Mariz, Severim de Faria and Manuel de Faria e Sousa, who rarely refer to him. Those who are more attentive (and also those who are in the know) realize that what existed between Luís and António was a loving relationship. Not a loving relationship as we would understand it today, but a connection with hierarchies, perhaps fixed places. Camões was much older, a washed-up man in his late forties; Jau was a newly racialized young Christian in Lisbon. It was certainly forbidden for him to walk wherever he wanted. On the street, I should go shopping and little else, or ask for him on the streets of Lisbon, as some say. At home, he acted as a nurse, perhaps a servant, perhaps a lover. In Camões literature, or literature that has recovered this theme, Jau plays several roles: faithful friend, canine, Camões's alter ego, confidant, soulmate or even subliminally a boyfriend, which comes to the surface in some less naive, more knowledgeable texts. After all, the smartest people understand what was encrypted so as not to be understood. In the biographies and literature produced on this topic (which even enchanted Portuguese, German and French romanticism: we have paintings, plays, poems – even operas, on the subject!), he usually accompanies the Poet in the ambiguity of friendship until the end of his life. But a slave friend. Tradition began, however, to identify him as a slave only after a saying by Manuel de Faria e Sousa. A commentator who they call fanciful, but who perhaps knew what he was doing. After all, isn't slavery a metaphor for love, which Camões himself uses? Whoever says Bárbara, says jau. It is an obvious literary metaphor about the chains of affection, a code shared between his closest friends and some later ones who understood the allusions, probably a humanist homosocial circle and their descendants. It has already been suggested that Jau had been bought and rescued in Goa by the Poet, who had gone into debt because of the servant; that this same Jau, who would be an interpreter, was shipwrecked with his master at the mouth of the Mecong and went with him to Mozambique and from there to Lisbon. Poignant legends, but unlikely, says Storck. In fact, António died before the poet, and the latter only managed to survive him for a few months. This is the little information we have. As the German biographer recalls, all slaves had to pay freight to come to the Kingdom and then, in Portugal, entry rights, owed to the King. Who would pay them, if not poor Luís? This shows that he was not a slave at all. Camões did not have the resources to make a blind man sing, let alone own a slave. Storck again: a Jau slave who spoke three languages ​​fluently (his Javanese, plus Chinese and Portuguese) would certainly not be cheap. There were even Jau slaves in Lisbon. There was no need for Luís to bring one from so far away. João de Barros bought one, apparently Chinese. But the historian had a broad purse, and the Poet not so much. Now, this memory also comes with regard to the recent film El cautivo (2025), by Amenábar, which tells how Miguel de Cervantes was captured by privateers and locked up for five years in an Algiers prison. There was some controversy when the film suggested the possible homosexuality of the national author. This issue is not new, and there are disputes in Spanish criticism about his sexuality. Were you accused of sodomy or not? At least here there is a discussion, while in Portugal the suggestions about the same in Camões are light, distant, flying. Fernando Arrabal, author of Un esclavo llamado Cervantes, explained that his biography, published in 1995, is based on a document, dated 1569, according to which Miguel de Cervantes was accused of homosexuality when he was 21 years old and condemned by the King of Spain to the amputation of his right hand and exile. Was that why Cervantes had no use of his arm? And there are Cervantists who in fact speak not only of their homosexuality but also recognize their Jewish origins. The latter also came forward for our Luís, through Fiama's pity. They are metaphors for each other, if we look closely. Things seen as other, prohibited, that must be kept secret, and for which only small, closed groups hold the hermeneutic key. But after all, these are things that are within so many. They are also metaphors for each other: being Jewish is a metaphor for homosexual, and vice versa. In addition to being, or having been, concrete possibilities of life, they are also signs for some life that is behind the sign, the verb or the image, and that we do not achieve. Amenábar takes sides, of course, and does it well, in a beautiful film that transforms Miguel into Scheherazade who, together with her lover, the Bey of Algiers, postpones his death with stories. I think it's an excellent film, as entertainment, even if it's too focused on Cervantes as a storyteller, when Cervantes is far from being just that. Our Spanish brothers, on the other hand, even found the film mild and not very sexualized. In Portugal it would perhaps be a scandal if they did something like that for Camões. Many would think that they wanted to muddy the water. A good film would be one that gave a face to his abandonment, in which only with Jau did he find refreshment. Mário Cláudio, Eugénio de Andrade and Alfredo Margarido were among the few who dared to go there. The point I want to reach is the following: it would not be so much to present a gay Camões, but rather to show how his life and work open up to other landscapes, also sexual, as Frederico Lourenço says in the entry on Love in the Camões Dictionary, by Aguiar e Silva. It's for the next centenary.

item.title: Macau Awards | Studio City hosts the 2026 edition in May
item.description: The ninth edition of the Macau Awards 2026 takes place on May 12th this year, promoted by Macau Business magazine and which aims to reward local figures and projects that stand out in the most varied areas. The awards ceremony will be hosted by Studio City. Paulo Azevedo, media entrepreneur and founder of the Project Asia Corp. group, and who presides over this initiative, states, cited in a statement, that “the Macau Awards are recognized as the largest multisectoral, intercommunity and multilingual event of its kind in Macau”. The official also believes that “this enormously prestigious annual program will continue to celebrate the notable achievements of institutions, companies and individuals who exceptionally contribute to the city’s development”. The awards ceremony, broadcast live last year, reached an audience of more than 110,000 people through online news and live broadcast platforms, according to the same official note. For this year, applications are now open, with a submission deadline of March 31st. The novelty lies in the creation of two new categories: the “My City – My Brand” awards, which “celebrate the contribution of those who, for generations, kept an idea, a business or a dream alive, often facing economic and social challenges”. The “Sustainability” awards recognize “those who stand out for helping Macau become more sustainable, acting more in line with ‘green’ energy”. In addition, there are 11 categories in the competition, namely “Leadership by Example”, “Entrepreneurship” or “Great Bay, among others. Jury voting takes place in April.

item.title: Hong Kong | “The Nature of Why”, by Paraorchestra debuts in Asia
item.description: The No Limits Festival, in Hong Kong, hosts this weekend, from Friday to Sunday, the show “The Nature of Why”, by Paraorchestra, in what is the Asian debut of this renowned show. It is a combination of theater, orchestral music and dance, in a show that is guided by inclusion The neighboring region of Hong Kong is preparing to host, this weekend, from February 27th to March 1st, the show “The Nature of Why”, by Paraorchestra, part of the No Limits Festival. The public can enjoy sessions that “in a fun way” combine different artistic expressions such as “theater, live orchestra music and contemporary dance”, in a “totally inclusive and immersive” show, describes an official note from the organization. In what promises to be a “unique and intimate piece”, there are important names to take into account: the well-known British conductor and artistic director of the Paraorchestra, Charles Hazlewood, and the “acclaimed” Australian choreographer Caroline Bowditch. On stage, the musicians and dancers of Paraorchestra, which has already received several awards for its performances, “intertwine with the audience to the sound of a live cinematic soundtrack”, composed by Will Gregory, from Goldfrapp. “The Nature of Why” is inspired by “the boundless curiosity of Nobel Prize-winning theoretical physicist Richard Feynman and his search for the meaning of the world”, being described as an “inspiring and thought-provoking work that experiments with the nature of performance”. “As unexpected interactions and moments of joy emerge on the softly lit stage, the artists, musicians and audience become one in a sonic adventure in which every moment is a surprise”, states the same note. It is clear, therefore, that the public is invited to participate in the show, in a “unique format”. Those watching “are invited to come up to the stage to be closer to the action, free to walk, use a wheelchair or sit wherever they want”. It will be possible to “observe from a distance or get as close as you want to the virtuoso musicians and incredibly agile dancers, creating your own experience of this magical performance”. From integration The Paraorchestra is the first professional orchestra in the world composed of musicians with and without disabilities, having made its debut at the closing ceremony of the London 2012 Paralympic Games. Last year, the group won the “Ensemble Award” from the Royal Philharmonic Society. The group is based in Bristol, UK, describing themselves as a “fearless collective of musicians with and without disabilities”, who together present “innovative musical experiences, pushing the boundaries of musical creation to create art with passion and purpose”. The artistic direction is in charge of Charles Hazlewood. The show takes place in the Kwai Tsing Theater auditorium. From everyone and with everyone This year's lineup for the No Limits Festival – which runs until May – is full of presentations that aim to demonstrate that everyone can participate and create art. The theme of this year, the eighth edition, is “All of us, in every way”, being “a call to rethink the value of diversity through inclusion”. The organization's objective, as stated on the festival's website, is to seek to establish “a commitment to transforming difference and diversity into possibilities and connections”, with the idea that “inclusive arts can create a space for understanding”, that is, “a space where the imaginative potential of diversity can be seen and shared”. Another show included in the No Limits Festival is the theatrical performance “Two Blind Women in the Snowy Tokugawa Nights – Sleeping Fires by Kuro Tanino”, presented at the end of March at the Studio Theater of the Hong Kong Cultural Center, This commissioned work “tells the story of the blind masseuse Iku and the young apprentice Saya”, revealing itself “through a poetic combination of soundscapes, dialogues, gestures and aromas”. "This new commissioned play portrays the difficulties and pleasures of women's daily lives, as well as the complex issues of trust, secrecy and suspicion experienced by the inhabitants of the remote, snow-covered mountain village where they live. Contrasting the bonds of tradition and the women's search for independence and belonging, the play portrays their friendship and struggles, as well as the harshness and beauty of the natural world that surrounds them", describes the official note about this event. This is the latest work by theater director Kuro Tanino, being staged by Tanino's Niwa Gekidan Penino theater company.

item.title: More Chinese New Year shows in the coming days
item.description: The Directorate of Tourism Services (DST) continues to organize, in the coming days, shows to celebrate the arrival of the Year of the Horse with fireworks. One of the initiatives is the holding of three editions of “2026 – Drone and Fireworks Shows”, where drones are introduced for the first time in this type of presentation, in a combination of “technology with art, increasing the sensation and appreciation of fireworks shows”, in order to “enrich festive experiences”. One of these presentations takes place today, the seventh day of Chinese New Year, and then on March 3, the fifteenth day of the first month of Chinese New Year. These shows take place in the bay next to the Macau Tower. Also noteworthy is the holding of the “Second parade of floats with cultural performances” on Saturday, the 28th, the 12th day of the Lunar New Year. Between 8pm and 9:30pm, and starting at Rua Norte do Patane, the parade also includes a cultural show in the Iao Hon Municipal Market Garden. There will be 17 floats in this parade, eight of them representing Government departments and the remaining nine from local tourist entities. The public will be able to watch this parade from its beginning, on Rua Norte do Patane, and along the pedestrian walkways on the parade route to the finishing point, in the Jardim do Mercado Municipal de Iao Hon. Galloping on ZAPE At ZAPE, the “Gala a gallop no ZAPE” initiative is taking place until the 1st of March, “in conjunction with Chinese New Year and Valentine's Day”, more specifically in the surrounding area between Rua de Cantão and Rua de Beijing. According to a note from DST, the aim is, “through installations characteristic of the festive season, to increase the festive atmosphere of the neighborhoods and the tourist attraction, attracting people to the community neighborhoods”. This “Gala galloping at ZAPE” has “the participation of ZAPE traders and several integrated tourism and leisure companies”, and includes the launch of promotional packages to attract more tourists.

item.title: Concert | “Classics on Strings” in March at CCM
item.description: March will be the time to host the “Clássicos em Cordas” concert, led by the Macau Orchestra, and which brings two violinists to the territory: Julian Rachlin and Sarah McElravy. Here's the opportunity to hear interpretations of compositions by Beethoven and Felix Mendelssohn Bartholdy The Macau Orchestra (OM) will be the protagonist of another classical music concert scheduled for March, namely on the 14th, and which will be performed in the large auditorium of the Macau Cultural Center (CCM). The concert will be directed by Julian Rachlin, considered a “world-renowned violinist”, as described in a note from the Cultural Institute (IC), which supports the show. Violinist Sarah McElravy also joins the stage. “String Classics” is the name of this show, which presents “a true feast of fascinating works for strings”, such as Beethoven’s “Coriolanus Overture”, Mozart’s “Symphony Concertante in E-flat Major” and “Symphony No. 3 in A Minor ‘Scottish'” by Feliz Mendelssohn Bartholdy, German composer and pianist. This last composition dates from 1829 and 1841, having been premiered in the city of Leipzig on March 3, 1842. It is one of the last major works composed by this master of Romanticism, with its composition beginning on a trip to Scotland. In the case of Beethoven's “Coriolanus Overture”, it lasts eight minutes and had its premiere in Vienna, in March 1807, and is known for having inaugurated two concert formats in the 19th century, namely the concert overture and the symphonic poem. Distinguished names In a note from the IC, the career of Julian Rachlin, born in Vienna, is described as an “internationally acclaimed Austrian violinist and violist”. Rachlin also collaborated “with numerous orchestras and several internationally renowned conductors for more than three decades”, and, in recent years, he was Principal Guest Conductor of the Royal Northern Sinfonia, in the United Kingdom. He also directed several international orchestras, such as the Oslo Philharmonic Orchestra and the Munich Philharmonic. Sarah McElravy, a Canadian violin and viola player, has performed on stage in Europe, America and Asia. She is “recognized for her exceptional technique, having collaborated with renowned orchestras and participated in several music festivals”. McElravy is seen as someone with “profound performance experience”, also dedicating herself “to promoting musical education, having founded a chamber music association in Mexico to bring world-class concerts to local communities”. The “Clássicos em Cordas” concert will last approximately one and a half hours, including an intermission. Tickets are now on sale, with prices ranging between 150 and 300 patacas.

item.title: Scam | Elderly loses 1.6 million in illegal scheme
item.description: An elderly man was scammed out of around 1.6 million Hong Kong dollars after believing he was investing in an alleged Macau casino scam, which promised gamblers guaranteed winnings. The case was reported yesterday by the Judiciary Police (PJ) with the man being lured into the scam by a contact he met online. According to the fraudster, if the elderly man played with him, through a mobile application, he would always win. The games were allegedly taking place in one of the local casinos. After winning HK$2,400 following a HK$1,000 bet, the man believed the scam was real and transferred HK$870,000 to an account indicated by the online contact. However, when the application started showing earnings of 2 million Hong Kong dollars, the man was unable to access the money. He was told that access was dependent on further transfers to the account, which the man did until he accumulated losses of 1.6 million Hong Kong dollars. At that time, and without being able to raise the money, he filed a complaint with the PJ. Crime | Asks for money to display online and ends up in discussion A 26-year-old man from the Interior was arrested after trying to steal 170,000 Hong Kong dollars, with the excuse that he wanted to make a video to show himself on social media. The case was revealed yesterday by the Judiciary Police (PJ) and took place last Saturday, in a casino in Cotai. According to the outlines presented, the detainee approached the member of a money exchange group, and asked him for permission to film with 170 thousand Hong Kong dollars in chips and show himself on social media. In return, the suspect promised to exchange money later in the respective amount. However, when he received the chips, the man tried to escape, which led to an argument with the victim. The case caught the attention of casino security, which alerted the authorities, who arrested the suspect. The group member is also being investigated for the crime of illegal money exchange. CPSP | Woman detained upon entering Macau A woman from the Interior was arrested by the Public Security Police Corps, after taking possession of a cell phone she found inside a bus, in December. The case was publicized yesterday, and the woman was detained on Thursday, when she tried to enter Macau through Portas do Cerco. Questioned by authorities, the woman acknowledged the crime, which she justified with “momentary greed”. The detainee also confessed that the cell phone was being used inside and that upon returning to Macau she did not bring the rest of the equipment. In turn, the owner of the cell phone, a tourist, also from the interior, valued the object at around 4,500 patacas, when she complained about the loss. The case was referred to the Public Prosecutor's Office and the woman is indicted for the crime of illegitimate appropriation in the case of accession or found property, which carries a prison sentence of up to one year.

item.title: Real Estate | Purchases tripled at the beginning of January
item.description: The year started with the highest number of transactions since 2018, with 384 housing purchases and sales. However, prices continue to fall, even if the reduction is increasingly slight In the first half of January, demand for housing more than tripled, with 384 deals registered, the highest for the first half of January since 2018, when 426 housing purchases and sales were recorded. The most recent figures were updated on the Financial Services Directorate (DSF) portal, and show that prices were stable, albeit with a slight reduction. According to official data, the market showed signs of vitality mainly in the Macau Peninsula, with the total number of transactions reaching 299, higher than the 96 recorded in the same period last year, a difference of 203 purchases and sales. The growth trend did not stop at the Peninsula. In the Taipa market, the number of transactions also more than doubled, with 58 transactions recorded at the beginning of this year, compared to 20 transactions last month. In Coloane, 27 housing purchases and sales were recorded, an increase compared to the nine recorded at the beginning of 2025. January's growth is equally significant when the comparison is made with the beginning of December last year. At the beginning of January, there were 297 more transactions than those registered at the beginning of the previous month, when there were 87. The market showed greater demand compared to data from the beginning of December in Macau, and in the Peninsula 96 transactions were registered, in Taipa 17 and in Coloane three transactions. The other side In relation to housing purchase prices, the beginning of January brought a slight reduction, to an average of 69,241 patacas per square meter. Compared to the same period last year, the data reveals a decrease in housing values ​​of around 0.92 percent. According to the most recent data, the highest prices were charged in Coloane, where the square meter reached 74,190 patacas. Prices on the Macau Peninsula were above what happens in Taipa, with a price of 69,499 patacas per square meter, while on the Peninsula the price was 66,867 patacas per square meter. However, the comparison with December shows a higher price reduction. At the beginning of the last month of last year, the average price per square meter was 78,838 patacas, while the most recent price was 69,241 patacas, which meant a reduction of 12.17 percent.

item.title: CEM | Cable installation affects roads and parking lots
item.description: The installation of cables and ducts, as well as adjustments to motorcycle parking lots carried out by CEM, Macao Water and the Traffic Affairs Bureau (DSAT), will lead to the temporary closure of several roads and parking spaces. Parking will be prohibited in some of the metered spaces on Rua da Alegria and Rua de Brás da Rosa, between February 22nd and March 14th; in parking spaces for motorcycles, spaces reserved for vehicles for people with disabilities and loading areas on Travessa do Bem-Estar and part of the metered parking spaces on Rua de Brás da Rosa between February 22nd and March 24th; and also in part of the parking meters, spaces for motorcycles and loading/unloading area on Rua de Tomé Pires, 14 and 24 de Março. Between February 23rd and March 14th, traffic will be limited on the section of Rua da Alegria between Rua de Brás da Rosa and Beco dos Ferreiros; in the section of Travessa do Bem-Estar between Rua de Brás da Rosa and Rua de Tomé Pires and in the section of Rua de Brás da Rosa near Jardim Cheong Meng. item.title: DSAL | Melco offers more than 60 vacancies for receptionist and doorman
item.description: Applications for the “Melco Resorts & Entertainment Hotel Operation Practices Plan” opened today, which will provide 62 job vacancies, 15 for receptionists, two for concierges, five for customer service center employees and 40 for concierges. According to information released yesterday by the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs (DSAL), the employment plan follows the concept of “first hiring, then training”. Admitted candidates will receive training for two years, provided by Melco, on knowledge of the hotel, services and operation of the service desk, interdepartmental skills. At the end, graduates receive a certificate from Macau's professional skills recognition system. Registration will be open until March 6th and applications can be submitted through the DSAL portal. A lecture is scheduled for March 10th to present the content of the training and the professional career development plan. Interviews will take place after the lecture.

item.title: Illegal pensions | Demanded fight against online advertisements
item.description: Song Pek Kei calls for a fight against those who publish advertisements on social media offering illegal accommodation in private homes, and for the accounts to be banned. Both the deputy and tourism entrepreneur Andy Wu highlight the poor supply of legal accommodation at affordable prices as one of the reasons for irregularities A few weeks before the Lunar New Year holidays, at the end of January, advertisements for renting rooms for tourists who were considering visiting Macau during the holidays began to appear on social media, especially Chinese ones. Although the phenomenon is not new to the region, some publications offered “beds” in Macau for between 100 and 150 renminbis. Song Pek Kei once again spoke out against illegal pensions. In an article published yesterday in the Citizen newspaper, the deputy linked to the Fujian community suggests that the Government establish a coordination mechanism with social networks, such as Douyin (Chinese TikTok), to eliminate publications offering rooms in illegal guesthouses and ban the accounts that share them. The deputy considers that, with the end of the pandemic and the paralysis of tourism, the phenomenon of illegal boarding houses has returned in force, with more cases compared to the past, following the increase in the number of tourists visiting Macau and the successive records of arrivals. It is recalled that in the first 20 days of the year, authorities inspected 25 apartments suspected of illegally providing accommodation, of which 17 were sealed. Song Pek Kei highlighted that illegal guesthouses persist based on two situations: unaffordable prices and low supply of budget hotels, and people staying in Macau too long. The deputy indicated that at the moment, around 6,000 people are in the territory overstaying. From the competition With hotel rooms at unmatched prices in Zhuhai, both Song Pek Kei and travel agency entrepreneur and association leader Andy Wu believe that the local low-cost hotel offer is not enough, despite legal changes that now allow the offer of capsule hotels. An opinion shared by the president of the Macau Tourism Industry Association, Andy Wu, who also told the Cidadão newspaper highlighted the limited supply of low-cost options. For the director, offering accommodation to tourists who are illegally in Macau harms the healthy development of the tourism industry. Furthermore, he pointed out that the prices between budget hotels and five-star hotels are not that different, especially on weekdays, and that they are far from the prices charged in Zhuhai, with rooms between 100 and 200 renminbi.

item.title: Suicide | Cáritas Support Line received around 30 calls per day
item.description: Between the 16th and 19th of this month, the last three days of the last lunar year, the Caritas suicide prevention helpline entitled Caritas LifeHope received around 30 calls daily. The number was indicated by the person responsible for the telephone line, Ng Lai Ieng, cited by the newspaper Ou Mun. The person in charge explained that the number of daily calls was similar to that on other business days. Ng Lai Ieng revealed that seven of these calls were requests for help related to suicide, but fortunately they were nothing more than thoughts, without any type of planning or associated action. Ng pointed out that in these cases the calls are classified as low-risk cases. The other requests for help were motivated by marital conflicts or problems adapting to situations of divorce, stress, and other cases of mental and emotional instability. Anyone who is emotionally distressed or considers themselves to be in a desperate situation should call the Caritas Hope for Life Hotline on 28525222 in order to obtain emotional counseling services.

item.title: Portugal | BNU and Misericórdia join the solidarity campaign
item.description: Six Portuguese-based entities in Macau and Hong Kong announced a fundraising campaign to help victims of the storms in Portugal. After Cáritas Macau, the solidarity wave encompasses BNU, Misericórdia, Casa de Portugal, Council of Portuguese Communities, Lusophone Scout Group of Macau and Club Lusitano After Cáritas Macau announced about two weeks ago that it was raising funds to help victims of the storms that affected Portugal and Spain in recent weeks, the solidarity campaign in Macau and Hong Kong was extended to six Portuguese-based entities. Monetary donations can go to an account at Banco Nacional Ultramarino (BNU), which has joined the initiative, according to a joint statement. The funds will then be redirected “to one or more Portuguese social solidarity institutions operating on the ground, ensuring transparency and traceability of the entire process”, they added in the same note. Recalling the “best tradition of fraternity and solidarity that unites Portuguese-speaking peoples”, the statement makes “a public appeal for the mobilization of the Portuguese-speaking community in Macau and the Greater Bay Area”. In addition to having the institutional support of the consulate, the campaign was launched by the Casa de Portugal association in Macau, the China Circle of the Council of Portuguese Communities and the Lusophone Scout Group of Macau. Long challenge In Hong Kong, the initiative has the participation of Club Lusitano, the largest institution of the Portuguese-descendant community of the former British colony, with around 400 members, founded in 1866. It is worth remembering that on February 10, the Catholic organization Cáritas Macau launched a three-month fundraising campaign for those affected by the storms in the Iberian Peninsula. In a note published on social media, the Catholic organization lamented the “devastating storms” that caused “catastrophic floods” and landslides in Portugal and Spain, destroying infrastructure and homes. "Thousands of people are homeless and urgently need water, food and medical care. Local teams work tirelessly, but the recovery will be long and challenging", warned Cáritas Macau. On Wednesday, the União das Misericórdias Portuguesas said it had received a donation worth 300 thousand euros from Misericórdia de Macau to support its counterparts who suffered significant damage caused by the Kristin depression. Nineteen people died in Portugal following the Kristin, Leonardo and Marta depressions, which also caused many hundreds of injuries and displacement. The total or partial destruction of homes, businesses and equipment, the fall of trees and structures, the closure of roads, schools and transport services, and the cut of energy, water and communications, floods and floods are the main material consequences of the storm. The Centre, Lisbon and Vale do Tejo and Alentejo regions were the most affected. The calamity situation that covered the 68 most affected municipalities ended on February 15th.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke long and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this error. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technique and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it.
